column2: <title></title>

column1: Management Accounting is een vakgebied dat zich richt op het verzamelen, ordenen, interpreteren, presenteren en gebruiken van cost accounting informatie ten behoeve van de besluitvorming door het management in organisaties.

Management accounting is derhalve veel meer dan louter rekenwerk of “number crunching” – het ultieme doel is de besluitvorming te ondersteunen en duurzame organisatiedoelen te bereiken. Dit vak geeft studenten een goede inleiding tot management accounting tools en technieken en de praktische toepassing hiervan voor moderne financiële managers. Studenten leren in dit vak hoe financiële en niet-financiële informatie te combineren, en op een vertrouwde manier met data-analyse om te gaan. Naast accounting en analytische vaardigheden, vereist management accounting een goed begrip van de organisatie, het businessmodel, de strategische context en positie in de markt, met aandacht voor duurzaam beleid.

De cursus zal het inzicht, de vaardigheden en het analytisch vermogen in management accounting van de student ontwikkelen tot het niveau waar hij/zij effectief kan functioneren als een professionele management accountant/financial controller in het bedrijfsleven, accountantskantoren, management consulting, of overheidsinstellingen</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Studenten die dit vak met succes hebben afgerond zijn specifiek in staat om:

column2: • De verschillende typen kosten in organisaties te classificeren (bv. productkosten vs. periodekosten, directe vs. indirecte kosten, vaste vs. variabele kosten) en diverse kostenconcepten te identificeren (bv. opportuniteitskosten, gezonken kosten, marginale kosten, gemiddelde kosten)
• Technieken in data-analyse te begrijpen, toe te passen, en resultaten te interpreteren, ter ondersteuning van de besluitvorming
• Kostenfuncties te ontwikkelen, cost-volume-profit analyses uit te voeren, en alternatieve kostenallocatietechnieken toe te passen
• Het budget proces in een organisatie te beschrijven en de budgetschema’s die samen het master budget vormen op te stellen
• Statische en flexibele budgetten te onderscheiden en variantieanalyses uit te voeren om prestaties te evalueren en verbeterplannen voor te stellen
• Implicaties voor organisaties van alternatieve modellen van responsibility accounting en prestatiemeting te bepalen
• Accounting informatie te selecteren die relevant is om interne plannings-, beleids- en beheersingsbesluiten te nemen

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100152,2021,Management and Leadership in Media Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

column1: The current challenges in media organizations and the media industry, such as the ongoing COVID-19 crisis, more generally a growing mediatization of organizations and society, rising competition, and an increasing complexity of organizational issues make managing and leading processes and practices of strategy and change highly relevant.

Therefore, the course provides an overview of key theories and topics around strategy, management and leadership and works towards their reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. Students will comprehend and evaluate classical and modern approaches from managing change and strategy to competitive forces, industry analysis, resources and strategy processes and practices.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication in strategic manner. Through diverse activities, students will apply these theories and approaches sensibly and creatively for learning how to develop successful actions in/for practice.

• Current concepts, approaches and theories of strategic management and leadership that are relevant for working in media organizations;
• How media organizations and practitioners strategically manage processes and practices around individuals, groups,  and organization-wide phenomena.
• Identify the need for and function of strategic management and leadership in their context;
• Apply strategy and leadership approaches and theories reflectively;
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.

column1: This course will provide insights into the complex topic of diversity in organizations and will examine how diversity can effectively be managed in organizations. At the end of the course, students understand the core diversity theories and empirical research insights, can critically evaluate the operation and effects of diversity across individual, team, and organizational levels, and apply their learnings to real-world diversity challenges by identifying how human resource management (HRM) can contribute to the effective management of diversity in organizations.  </body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
<tbody>

column4: Having an understanding of the core diversity theories and most relevant scholarly insights on diversity.
Being able to approach diversity from a holistic perspective considering its complexity operating across levels (individual, team, organization) and contexts.
Being able to apply diversity theory and research to real-world challenges around the management of diversity.
Knowing how to have meaningful and evidence-based discussions about the management of diversity at work.
Using an evidence-based mindset to approach diversity management in the most effective way.
Being able and willing to critically reflect upon on one’s own perceptions about diversity.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100202,2021,Management of Media and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. HJCJ Hitters'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This seminar focuses on organizational aspects of the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of firms. The central question is to what extent firms in the media and cultural industries are different from other firms with respect to initiating, managing and controlling business processes. This question will be analyzed from three angles. We will first systematically and critically assess the nature and structure of creative media markets, in which symbolic or experience value plays an important role and companies have to operate in a dynamic field of continuous technological, social and cultural transformations. Secondly, whereas most management literature centers on strategies of large cross-media corporations, in this seminar we aim at understanding the conduct and business ventures of small-scale enterprises and entrepreneurs (SMSE’s). These are mostly positioned at the beginning of the creative value chain: the phase of concept and idea creation and the first stages of production. After all, at this stage successful management of creativity is crucial to innovation. The third angle examines the relationship between incumbents and new enterprises in the media and creative industries. Here we will focus on issues such as innovation failure, routines, leadership and transformation. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The specific character of organization and management in the media and creative industries.
• Current theories, approaches and debates in this field.
• Systematically analyze and critically reflect on fundamental and practical challenges in managing and organizing contemporary media and creative industries firms.
• Analyze independently an empirical case study.
• Find alternatives and solutions for challenges that media and creative companies are facing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102409,2021,Management van technologie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['MJ Iwanczuk-Prost', 'prof.dr. DA Stam']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Technologie is al eeuwenlang één van de belangrijkste pijlers van de economie. Zowel in de productiegerichte sectoren als in dienstverlenende bedrijven speelt technologie een belangrijke rol. Zonder technologische vooruitgang verliezen bedrijven concurrentiekracht. Managers staan voor de vraag op welke manier zij optimaal gebruik kunnen maken van technologie. Welke technologie is beschikbaar en welke technologische ontwikkelingen zijn gaande? Welke gevolgen kan technologie hebben voor een bedrijf, een sector en de maatschappij? Welke betekenis heeft technologie voor de strategie van het bedrijf wat betreft de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties? Kortom, hoe kunnen managers technologieën herkennen en op een juiste wijze inpassen binnen het bedrijf? In dit vak zul je een technologie strategie ontwikkelen voor een high-tech technologie toegepast in een kernproduct van het casebedrijf door technische en bedrijfskundige criteria te combineren.

Het vak staat in het teken van management van “high-tech” technologieën. Je zult kijken naar een specifieke “high-tech” technologie die een essentieel onderdeel is van een product (B2B of B2C) van het bedrijf dat jouw case heeft ingebracht. Deze technologie kan echter verouderen vanwege opkomende nieuwe technologieën. De opkomende technologieën hebben dezelfde functionaliteit als de huidige technologie, maar zouden (in de toekomst) meer waarde kunnen toevoegen aan het product van het bedrijf en zijn klanten. Daarom is het belangrijk om de technologische ontwikkelingen te volgen en te overwegen om voor een opkomende technologie te kiezen om de concurrenten voor te blijven. Hierbij gaat het niet om de vraag hoe aan een marktvraag kan worden voldaan door middel van technologie (“market pull”), maar hoe technologieën kunnen worden benut voor de vernieuwing van de producten/diensten, de productieprocessen, en de kerncompetenties van een bedrijf (“technology push”).

Het is echter niet vanzelfsprekend om over te stappen op een (technologisch gezien) beter alternatief. Het introduceren van een opkomende technologie kan grote effecten hebben op het product, het productieproces, het bedrijf zelf en zijn omgeving. Daarom moeten managers de opkomende en de huidige technologieën zorgvuldig evalueren en met elkaar vergelijken, inclusief hun effecten. De hoofdvraag in dit vak luidt dan ook: moet het bedrijf overstappen op een van de opkomende technologieën?

Het doel van het vak is het schrijven van een strategisch plan voor een bestaand bedrijf (case bedrijf) met een high-tech product waarin een alternatieve technologie kan worden toegepast. Om dit doel te behalen moet je eerst de huidige situatie verkennen (opdracht 1). Daarna zul je geschikte opkomende technologieën analyseren en hun eventuele impact op het bedrijf onderzoeken (opdracht 2). Vervolgens combineer je deze informatie in een voorstel voor een technologie strategie (opdracht 3), welke je zult samenvatten tijdens een presentatie voor je medestudenten.

Het vak kan gerelateerd worden aan SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Onderdeel van opdracht 2 en 3 is het in acht nemen van de (maatschappelijke) omgeving bij de implementatie van de opkomende technologieën.

column1: Strategic management is concerned with what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate growth strategies, identify core capabilities, and develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals. Firms are also increasingly confronted with more multifaceted environments such as business ecosystems as well respond to rapid technological innovations, such as for example new digital technologies. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge and skills needed to accomplish these activities and navigate the strategic decision-making process in an increasingly uncertain and complex business environment.

The emphasis in this class lies not on identifying the “right” answer, instead the focus is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures, plenary discussions, guest lectures, webcasts, group exercises and case work. Students are expected to prepare the assigned material and webcasts prior to each class in order to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete in-class group exercises.</body>

column2: <title></title>

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To describe the value of scientific research for business strategy practice;
• To integrate different theoretical perspectives to develop business strategies under uncertainty and ambiguity to realize organizational goals;
• To evaluate what capabilities influence firms’ ability to successfully outperform its competitors in dynamic industries;
• To analyze present strategic problems and opportunities at the business level;
• To create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for addressing these present issues; and
• To give oral presentations about a strategic problem within a company.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100008,2021,Managing Cultural Heritage,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>By studying relevant literature on cultural heritage management, students will gain knowledge of the intertwining character of heritage, tourism, economy, culture and (local) identity. Subsequently they will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete case studies which will require them to carry out field work on location. The course will highlight the strategies that can be put in place to ensure the better preservation possible of cultural heritage while stimulating tourism. Literature discussions, interviews and field trips will provide a varied didactic program with a hands-on attitude.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete real-life cases. Students become familiar with the major trends and challenges in the world of cultural heritage management and how heritage management could go together with place-making and the creation of sustainable tourism. Moreover, students will gain knowledge of the experiences of various actors in the field of cultural heritage management and their insider’s view on current developments.

column1: There is a growing realization that organizational success and the ability of organizations to gain a competitive advantage is critically contingent on effective management of people. This course aims to develop an in-depth understanding of the social, psychological, and organizational factors that shape individuals’ behaviour at work and allow for effective collaboration, covering topics such as motivation, decision making, team composition and effective collaboration, and power dynamics. Building on BA teaching in OB and HRM, in this course we will deepen this knowledge and place a particular emphasis on the link between theory and managerial practice. The resulting principles of people management are a valuable part of any future manager’s toolbox, but they are particularly critical for future HR professionals.

The course proceeds in a highly interactive way, each class combining multiple different learning activities. Selected book chapters and academic articles provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class. Lecture elements supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material. Experiential exercises and simulations deepen the insight on specific social and psychological phenomena. Case discussions train the application of course knowledge to solve managerial problems. During the course, students are expected to actively participate in class discussions and activities.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Apply organizational behavior theories in order to analyze challenges facing current-day organizations.
• Develop theoretically sound and practical recommendations to challenges related to managing individuals and teams in organizations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100300,2021,Managing Innovation Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. H Fasaei'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not strategically managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate successfully, and thus fail to create meaningful value for their customers.

In this course, we will learn how firms could create and capture meaningful value for their customers. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts and theories as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation more strategically.

The format of the course is intense, but allows you to focus on the subject matter and to have engaging debates and discussions in the classroom. Consequently, the course will provide you with an insightful and fun learning environment. Applying the theoretical and practical knowledge is a central aspect of this course. Therefore, it will include several practical examples and cases.

All sessions will be highly interactive, with ample room for discussion, group presentations focusing on applying the theory to practical examples, and small group exercises. The approach is strongly participative and based on the co-creation method of learning. Co-creation involves developing deeper relationships between you and me as the facilitator, and between you and other learning partners in the class. Education is perceived as a shared endeavor where learning and teaching are done with you not to you. Co-creation method of teaching and learning is therefore a collaborative, reciprocal process through which all participants have the opportunity to contribute equally, although not necessarily in the same ways, to curricular or pedagogical conceptualization, decision making, implementation, investigation, or analysis.

Each week, we will have team assignments to be prepared for the next session. You will be working on an assignment pertinent to the theme and content of the next session during the week, and you will then present your outcome of the assignment in terms of a short presentation in the next session, and we will have profound and in-depth discussions about your presentations. This way, we will learn a lot by doing and by engaging in intellectual discussions and debates. In order to have interesting sessions and to benefit from them to the fullest, you need to come to the class well-prepared.

At the end of the lecture series, you will be asked to demonstrate your understanding of managing innovation strategically in an individual assignment. This individual assignment will cover all materials of the course (i.e., material covered during sessions, assigned readings and academic articles, selected assigned videos, slides of lectures, and insights that you collect during sessions via discussions). The assignment will be a take-home assignment and include some questions about the application of theories, concepts, and models that we discussed in this course based on a real company. Questions will be open questions and will cover the application and synthesis of concepts, models, and theories covered in the course and its underlying lectures, slides, videos, and readings.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand the importance of managing innovation strategically
• Remember, understand and analyze the determinants of managing innovation strategically and its underlying challenges

• Analyze, apply, and evaluate the theories and concepts of the course to be able to use various techniques related to design thinking, value creation, and disruptive innovation to manage innovation strategically
• Analyze and apply the theories and concepts of the course to be able to create innovative experiences and to manage innovation strategically through the art of persuasion and storytelling

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive forms of governance are on the rise in many countries. They refer to processes in which multiple governmental and non-governmental actors interact in formulating or implementing public policy. services and decision-making. In addition to other courses in the Master programs, this course pays specific attention to both government-induced forms of interactive governance (e.g. citizen participation) and citizen-induced forms of interactive governance (e.g. community-based initiatives and community-led co-production). The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects; the latter indicates that citizens themselves show self-organizing capacity and initiative for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: sustainable energy, health and urban development.

These interactive forms of governance offer important potential for enhancing effectiveness, public support, empowerment and democratic quality of policy and decision-making processes, but are also challenging existing ways of working within governments. Moreover, they are not self-executive and a variety of factors and obstacles may prevent this potential to become manifest. They could also raise issues of accountability, inclusion and transparency. This course focuses on the potential and challenges of interactive governance and how specific management strategies and process designs could deal with these challenges and how they could enhance the democratic quality and effectiveness of interactive governance.

In a systematic way, the various conditions and barriers for effective and legitimate interactive governance are discussed. Secondly, relevant strategies, behavior and skills of managers are discussed to deal with these barriers. In this regard specific attention is paid to boundary spanning activities and skills in connecting governmental and non-governmental actors. Thirdly, a hands-on and reflective approach is taken. Students are challenged to critically reflect on cases and literature and to formulate practical advice to managers engaged in interactive governance.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After completion of the course students are able:

column2: • To understand the differences between government-induced (participation) and citizen-induced (self-organization) interactive governance approaches and processes;
• To apply different perspectives on interactive governance;
• To analyze barriers and challenges of government- and citizen-induced interactive governance;
• To formulate critical conditions for effective and legitimate government- and citizen-induced interactive governance;
• To determine management strategies for interactive governance fitting specific case study circumstances and situations;
• To formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with interactive governance processes and projects.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope. In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time, use ally. New parties are playing an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

What is often forgotten as an important actor in society is the civil society sphere in which philanthropic nongovernmental and non-profit organizations are active. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as the need for distributing medical care for those who have little access to it, to reduce poverty, reduce emissions, save the whales or advocate for human rights. Many of them are focused upon advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, the context in which these NPOs and NGOs operate is very diverse (maybe even more diverse!). Just like for-profit organizations, many different types of NPOs and NGOs exist. Just like for-profit organizations, these organizations serve a mission and have their particular strategies. As such, just like for-profit organizations, these organizations need to be managed properly in order to achieve their goals. In this course, you will see however, that the way in which these organizations are managed, is completely different than in the for-profit or governmental sector.

During the elective, you will be provided with a theoretical and practical background of the management of philanthropic, non-profit and nongovernmental organizations. During a number of guest lectures, organizations will provide an insight into the management of their NPO or NGO. During these lectures, specific themes within management of philanthropic organizations are highlighted and investigated. Moreover, fieldtrips to NPOs/NGOs will be arranged for you to be able to take a look into what really happens at these organisations.

The research notes will prepare you for the lectures and assignments. The individual assignment will teach you to actively connect research and practice based up on pragmatic real-life issues of NPOs/NGOs. With your group, you will create your own (fictional) NPO/NGO based on a real-life issue of your choice.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this elective, you will be able to

• Analyse the management aspects non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organizations;

• Understand, analyse and evaluate the way in which the civil society sphere creates impact and interacts with and is related to the business and the governmental sphere.

column1: This is a course on how in this digital age to create, foster, and manage organizations in which people thrive and perform at their best. It assumes that employee and group flourishing is key to organizational excellence in our quickly changing, complex and ambiguous world. The challenge in managing from this perspective is how do you architect contexts (jobs, organizational cultures, structures, processes) that enable employees and groups to thrive? The challenge at a more personal level, is how do you find and/or create a context in which you can thrive and manage at your best.

The course will help students how to build organizations that are typified by virtuousness, meaningfulness, creativity, collaboration, and focus on human well-being and creating abundance. Employees of such organizations experience trust, respect, high levels of positive energy, positive spirals of flourishing, and self-fulfillment.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Learn theories from the field of positive organizational scholarship.
• Learn a conceptual framework that links individual flourishing and facilitating contexts (jobs, teams, and organization).
• Learn how to enhance a sense of purpose and meaning in a quickly changing world.
• Learn about HR tools to apply theory in organizational practice.
• Understand and know how to work with personal strengths and capabilities.
• Design and manage interventions for individual thriving and facilitating organizational contexts.
• Assess the value and evidential value of a strengths approach.

column1: Companies of all kinds -- manufacturing or services – believe that their customers are most important and valuable assets. Strong customer focus is often identified as the most important
differentiator between the best and the worst companies. Hence, managing customer experience and guaranteeing a certain service level is of paramount importance.

Performance management in manufacturing and service companies is often complex because the performance is affected by coordination requirements among multiple resources and the customer. To understand the objective of this course better, consider “time” as the performance measure reflecting customer experience. For instance, in a manufacturing system, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires coordination among several resources such as, supplier (providing the raw material), planner (planning the machine capacity), scheduler (scheduling the job), worker (working on machine setup), and machine (processing the job). Therefore, lower is the coordination delays among the resources, better is the performance measure positively affecting the customer experience. Likewise, in a service system such as a restaurant, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires minimizing coordination delays among the tables (seating the customer), order takers (taking the order), and kitchen resources (preparing the food). Hence, to manage manufacturing and service system performance, there is a growing importance on analyzing the system and estimating the measures that are good indicators of customer experience such as customer “waiting time.”

This course will focus on approaches to estimate the performance measures and design systems for superior performance. The complexities in managing customer performance are further increased because of the sources of uncertainties present in the system such as uncertain number of customer arrivals. The students will also learn approaches to manage system performance in the presence of business uncertainties. Through this course, the students will develop skills in building quantitative models for manufacturing and service systems, which can be analyzed rapidly to provide insights for decision making. We will also try to incorporate behavioural aspects of service and manufacturing operations in the quantitative models. The skills will be developed through a mix of concept lectures, cases, experimenting with software tools, and a course project.  Some prior exposure to simulation tools will be helpful to keep pace with the course learnings.

The students will develop analytical thinking and learn to deal with practical issues while executing the course project, develop skills for quick performance analysis of systems, and also learn to develop managerial insights from models, which is an important skill to possess for executing complex on-the-job assignments in manufacturing and service organizations. The concepts discussed in each lecture will build on the learnings from the previous lectures. Hence, the students are advised to prepare thoroughly with the course material. A detailed course outline will be posted on Canvas.

column1: Professional organizations are ubiquitous: consultants spread new management theory, designers and engineers develop physical environments, auditors review the accounts of companies, and when something goes wrong, lawyers step in. As such organizations rely on highly skilled professionals as their main production force, several peculiar challenges in managing them arise. The purpose of this elective is to familiarize students with these challenges and provide with practical tools for overcoming them. We will consider professional organizations for officially accredited professionals such as lawyers and accountants, as well as for IT experts, consultants, and creative professionals. The course will focus on two broad questions: (1) how are professional organizations structured, governed, and managed internally? (2) how do professional organizations interact with high velocity environments in which they operate? We will first examine the defining features of professional organizations. Further, we will discuss the implications of expert knowledge centrality for them, and study forms of governance typical for professional organizations. Subsequently, we will discuss how professional organizations interact with their clients and how organization members manage the tension between economic and professional goals. We will conclude by discussing some global trends relevant for professional organizations.

• demonstrate basic skills of data collection using web-sources or personally conducted interviews.

column1: Public and private organisations are now confronting highly volatile multi-level political, economic and environmental realities. Global destabilization is underway involving key uncertainties characterized by climate breakdown, the dwindling influence of Western dominated international institutions, the rise of non-governmental influence and anti-establishment social movements, all in the midst of a new technological revolution which will see the rise of automation, artificial intelligence and the dismantling of traditional labour-capital frameworks. This course seeks to help you understand how societal organisations prepare for this future. It introduces you to the idea of how best to manage societal and institutional transitions within the context of global destabilization through robustly planning for strategically developed future scenarios. The course involves a twin track process of (1) lectures that give you a grounding on key uncertainties facing organisations and then (2) group work where you understand how to scenario plan based upon approaches used by organsations such as Royal Dutch Shell and a wide range of other private and public institutions. The written examination will then focus on the lecture material on key uncertainties in global societal and institutional transitions, whilst the group project examines your group work on scenario planning on behalf of a private or public organisation of your choice.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Learning goals. By the end of this course, students will be able to;

column2: • Identify the ways in which government, business and NGOs plan for future transitions
• Apply future scenario planning on behalf of an organisation
• Explain the changing roles of institutions in guiding society through transitions
• Explain how societal actors seek to exert influence by strategizing possible futures
• Explain key uncertainties such as climate change, the technological revolution and the rise of new powers
• Identify the main challenges and opportunities for governing transitions

column1: Utilize approaches to assess plans, strategies, policy documents and institutional arrangements for transitions</body>

column1: Family firms are ubiquitous across space, time and industries. Family businesses do not only represent small, private companies. Founders or founding families are important controlling owners of large corporations listed on stock exchanges around the world. Famous examples of family businesses are IKEA, Harley Davidson and Heineken. As such, family businesses represent a very important force for the economic and social development anywhere in the world. At the same time, family control raises unique value-creating opportunities as well as challenges for family businesses and their different stakeholders, such as customers, financiers, suppliers, partners, employees, board members and owners.

This course introduces students to the widespread, yet complex, phenomenon of family business. It touches upon several important themes, such as strategy development, succession, governance, conflicts, business continuation, and more. The aim of this course is to introduce concepts and practical learning situations which will help the students to make sense of family businesses and to assist them in better understanding and dealing with the unique opportunities and challenges faced by different family business stakeholders.

The course is specially designed for those who are interested in working in family businesses (e.g., as managers and/or owners) or with family businesses (e.g., as advisors or consultants), and for those coming from a family business background themselves. Whatever their future role will be, students will find it useful to understand the uniqueness of these organizations. During the course, the students will develop their own perspective on family business. After the course, the students should be able to apply in practice appropriate models and theories presented during the course, as well as critically examine models and theories regarding family business development.

column1: After completion of the course, the student will be able to:

• Describe and explain the main theories and concepts within the field of family business research and practice
• Analyze and apply family business theories and concepts to different critical situations faced by family businesses
• Critically evaluate the use of concepts and models to understand family businesses
• Reflect upon common challenges faced by family businesses in practice, and develop a way to address these challenges

• Demonstrate an ability to think critically by identifying, analyzing and providing concrete solutions to complex problems, both in a team and individually

column1: Through drawing on both Global History and International Relations Theory this course explores the concept and history of global order from 1500 through to the present. First, this course reflects on the nature and characteristics of order and order building, through asking questions like: What is international order? What international ordering mechanism have been developed to globalise conceptions of international order? How is international hierarchy legitimised? And how and why do revisionist powers emerge? Second, this course examines key episode in the history of global order, from the first European imperial cycle, through the Atlantic Revolutions, the second European imperial cycle, to the Pax Americana and the normative and geopolitical challenges to American –  and Western – hegemony in the 21st century.

This course has a substantial workload, both in terms of reading and assignments, but as such it constitutes an excellent first step towards identifying a topic for the MA thesis as well as researching and writing up the MA thesis.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Drawing on History and IR, students can conceptualise power, global order and related concepts;
• Students can analyse and compare episodes of international primacy in world history;
• Students can discern various scholarly views on the rise and decline of primacy and how this affects the global order;
• Students navigate, criticise and defend scholarly opinions to develop substantiated views on key episodes of the history of power and global order.

column1: This course examines the complex legal relations and liabilities which arise when a ship at sea is in distress and/or suffers a maritime casualty. The course gives an overview of the many international legal instruments which (may) apply to various as-pects of a maritime casualty. It addresses the various mechanisms designed to pre-vent maritime casualties and marine pollution from occurring by raising the technical and safety standards of and on board of ships. These mechanisms include Flag- and Port-State Control, the Paris MoU and the role of Classification Societies.

Other subjects covered in depth include the law of Collision, Salvage, General Ave-rage, Limitation of Liability of the ship-owner, Civil Liability for Oil Pollution damage and Wreck Removal. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay questions. Several lectures and/or workshops will be taught by guest lecturers from maritime practice.</body>

column1: Interviews, transcripties en analyses zullen worden opgenomen in de collectie van het Maritiem Museum Rotterdam; en aldus beschikbaar zijn voor gebruik in museale activiteiten en voor verder wetenschappelijk onderzoek. De meerwaarde van interviews is het documenteren van aspecten, die in andere bronnen niet vastgelegd (kunnen) zijn, speciaal hoe mensen ontwikkelingen ervaren en beleefd hebben.

Het programma is zo opgezet dat workshops niet elke week, maar om de week plaatsvinden. In de week dat er geen bijeenkomst is kan alle aandacht uitgaan naar het voorbereiden van de workshops en andere opdrachten. Op deze manier is het honours programme goed te combineren met andere (studie)verplichtingen.

Het Maritieme Honours Programme staat open voor deelnemers, die voldoen aan criteria die gesteld worden aan het honours programma voor masterstudenten van de Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication. Daartoe kwalificeren ook excellente bachelor studenten, PhDs of erfgoed professionals.</body>

column1: <body>Na voltooiing van het Maritiem Honours Programme hebben deelnemers hun academische, specifiek historische, professionaliteit (op minimaal masterniveau) versterkt door:

column2: • hun kennis te verdiepen over de moderne geschiedenis van havens, de Rotterdamse haven in het bijzonder;
• waarbij de nadruk ligt op het werken in de haven en speciaal hoe havenarbeiders hun werk beleefd hebben, dat door technologische veranderingen sinds 1960 ingrijpend veranderde;

• het inzicht te verwerven in het functioneren van een wereldhaven anno 2021 door het organiseren en inhoudelijk voorbereiden van een bezoek aan een bedrijf, organisatie of locatie in de (Rotterdamse) haven;
• zich verder te bekwamen in de onderzoeksmethode oral history door theoretische kennis op dit terrein te verdiepen en een aantal interviews af te nemen met (oud-)havenarbeiders;
• tevens te leren deze gesprekken voor te bereiden, transcriberen en analyseren volgens de standaard die het Maritiem Museum Rotterdam hanteert voor zijn collectie;
• aldus de museale collectie inhoudelijk te verrijken en breder toegankelijk te maken;
• de uitkomste vast te leggen in een kleine paper;
• en te presenteren aan de staf van het Maritiem Museum Rotterdam;
• indien mogelijk, ook breder te presenteren aan het museumpubliek, tijdens historicidagen, in een vlog op Maritiem Portal of anderszins.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102091,2021,Market & Systemic Risk Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. C Zhou', 'prof.dr. CG de Vries']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Instructors: Prof. Casper G. de Vries (EUR) and Prof. C. Zhou (EUR)

The main objective of this course is to develop a coherent framework for evaluating market risk at the levels of individual asset, portfolios of assets, banks and insurers and the macro economy. The main tool that we exploit in devising this framework is the statistical theory about tail risk from Extreme Value Theory (EVT) in combination with standard concepts from finance and macroeconomics.

In particular, the course offers different methods to manage financial risk with special emphasis on downside risk measures such as Value-at-Risk (VAR), Expected Shortfall (ES), semi-variance, CVaR, Stress tests, worst case scenario analysis, etc. Various statistical techniques are studied for analyzing heavy-tailed distributions, especially their convolution properties. The heavy-tail feature refers to the phenomenon that very bad outcomes occur more frequently than the normal distribution predicts. The techniques are used to estimate and manage downside risk, both at individual asset level and portfolio level. Subsequently, we investigate the EVT for the sake of stress testing and scenario analysis. Given the link between individual risk management and stability of the financial system, we also pay attention to various aspects of risk management from a supervisory point of view. The inherent fragility of the financial system is explained and tools for measuring systemic stability are developed.

Students have to conclude empirical homework as well as addressing theoretical questions. A PC lab session is held to implement the novel techniques, using market data. The rigorous treatment of some of the techniques enables students to independently analyze market and systemic risk.
Lecture 1: Introduction, Motivation, Heavy Tail Evidence; Feller’s Convolution Theorem
Lecture 2: Application of Feller’s Theorem to Risk Measures; Extreme Value Theorem
Lecture 3: Cross Section and Time Dependence; Univariate Estimation
Lecture 6: Applications to Value at Risk, Systemic Risk

column1: In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace? How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market. The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three C’s (customers, company and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four P’s (product offering, pricing, promotion and physical distribution).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • Define the concept of marketing;
• Understand the fundamental principles of marketing, the key elements in developing and planning a marketing strategy, and the determinants of consumer behaviour;
• Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts;
• Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings;
• Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories;
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

• Given the description of a real-world marketing problem, students will be able to:
o develop a marketing research design
o propose and/or compare suitable data sources
o propose and/or compare suitable marketing models
• Given the output table of a marketing model, students will be able to:

• Given the examples in the practical sessions, students will be able to collect and analyze data for similar marketing problems.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: “Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that rely on data to improve marketing decisions. This exciting field continues to grow in its scope and importance as the amount of data available to companies increases. Many large companies now have dedicated business analytics groups, and companies of all sizes are looking to hire marketing managers with a mix of technical and practical knowledge.

This course provides students with hands-on experience using many of the tools employed by marketing analysts. The purpose of this hands-on experience is not to develop students into analysts, but rather to help them understand the value and limits of these tools, and to develop the ability to communicate analytical insights to less technical stakeholders.
Pre-requisites. The course assumes students are already familiar with marketing concepts and terminology presented in the core courses.
Topics covered. The course is divided into 12 modules:

column2: • Course overview, statistics review, and introduction to R
• Linear regression and binary logistic regression
• Modeling consumer preferences with utility functions
• Estimating preferences from choice data
• The grammar of graphics and exploratory data visualization
• Communicating with data visualization
• Loading and tidying data
• Aggregate market data and demand estimation
• Customer lifetime valuation
• Targeted promotions
• Working with text data
• Sentiment analysis and topic models

column1: Overview of workload. There are two modules per week. Each module has assigned reading, 1–2 graded assessments, a discussion board, and a live lecture session. The workload should average to about 28 hours per week (each ECTS is equal to 28 hours of study).
Course structure. Modules generally proceed according to the following sequence of activities:

column2: • Students read assigned material, and/or complete an R tutorial
• Students complete a short assignment to test their comprehension of the assigned material.

• Students post, read, and reply to questions on the discussion board for this module. Students can use this opportunity to indicate what material they want the instructor to emphasize in the lecture session.
• Students attend a lecture session with the instructor lasting 1.5–2.75 hours, during which further explanations and examples are provided and discussed.
• Students answer questions and conduct analysis while completing relatively longer problem set assignments. These problem set assignments usually include material from more than one module.

column1: Course attendance. Attendance is not graded. In addition to the two types of graded assignments already mentioned, students can earn points by marking items as completed in Canvas.

Assignments. All assignments are individual, and completed through Canvas. Comprehension assignments are due prior to the lecture. Problem set assignments are due at least a few days or a week after the live session. There are many assignments, each contributing a relatively small amount to your final grade.

<body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations need to generate more income from private sources such as ticket sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, e.g., having a clear and appealing identity, communicating and bonding effectively with their audiences, or offering arrangements attracting new audiences. Thus, arts organizations need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. Marketing is an indispensable tool to shape the relation with the public into a meaningful mutual commitment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will introduce students to the principles of art marketing. On the one hand, students will learn which characteristics of potential audience members determine their interest in the arts and how this interest may be increased. On the other hand, students are introduced to marketing strategies employed by cultural organizations and the rationale behind them.</body>

column1: A limited group of 20-25 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd and 4th block of their studies. During the sessions, faculty members and marketing practitioners will discuss relevant and current themes in marketing, such as branding and social media.

Researchers within the department will present their own and others’ latest research in these areas and discuss it with the students. Practitioners and alumni will be invited to some of the sessions to give the programme a more applied flavour. The programme will also feature company visits. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation consisting of reading and summarizing relevant literature. Cooperation will be sought with external partners, who will discuss the topics from their practical perspective.

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Marketing Management. The selection process will be based on a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS).</body>

column1: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies create value?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

As said, the course will be taught via a blend of (online) lectures and (case) discussions. During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight application and implementational issues.

Marketing management is not a “hard science”. There are, however, a number of theories and concepts that you need to master in order to understand and manage marketing. You will be asked to demonstrate your competences in an exam that consists of a series of open/ essay type questions. The exam will be “open-book” and will cover all the materials that have been discussed during lectures and made available through Canvas. Furthermore, all course readings (these will be made available through the university library before the course starts) will be exam material as well. Please check SIN Online for the exact timing of the exam and the resit.
The minimum grade requirement is 5.5. Please check the Examination Regulations page so that you are aware of the rules and regulations at RSM and for the MiM programme.

Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge through analyzing and creating solutions for and approaches to marketing and business problems. Finally, the course should make you familiar with academic research in marketing (science).

column1: Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

column1: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies develop a competitive advantage according to the marketing concept?” and “How is marketing affected by the use of social media?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight implementation issues as they are relevant for managers.

During the case discussions, you will be expected to analyse realistic problem situations in the form of business cases. While developing solutions, you will make use of core concepts in marketing and you will learn to apply them to a concrete case. As in actual practice, cases are characterized by a limited time frame for making decisions, incomplete information, and no clear ""best"" answer. The case method is essential to developing the kind of problem-solving and communication skills highly valued in the managerial practice. The ability to generalize from the specific case situations discussed in class to new situations that you may encounter is one of the foundations of management education.

During case discussions, a poorly prepared class invariably leads to an unrewarding experience for all involved. Thus, the long-term benefits from this course will be proportional to the extent that you make this course your project. This means that you are expected to come to class prepared and to actively participate. Specifically, you are expected to contribute to an informed exchange about the topic of the class and to have well-developed points of view about the cases and other reading material.

column1: In today’s world oversupplied with media and entertainment content, the task of marketing movies, TV shows & channels, music, video games and comparable products is increasingly challenging. In a highly competitive environment, go-to-market strategies determine the product’s success or failure. In this course fundamental theories and perspectives on how entertainment is being marketed today are addressed.  Why and how is marketing media and entertainment products different to marketing products from any other sector? How is targeting fans different from reaching “traditional” target groups? These are central questions in the course. Furthermore, course topics include ‘positioning an entertainment property as a brand’, ‘building creative brand-centric strategies’, ‘creating products’ synergies’, ‘ecosystems and partnerships’, and ‘understanding how the digital world has impacted marketing and distribution’. The course allows students not only gain theoretical knowledge about the key aspects of leading strategic approaches, but also to learn how to translate them into actionable plans.

column1: Marketing is the interface between a firm and its environment. It is the managerial practices that ensure customer-oriented managerial actions, including product design, pricing, market communication and product distribution, generate value for “customers”. The basic tenet is that managers should be able to justify that intended value-creation actions lead to sufficient customer responses such that they surpass the costs of these actions. However, in practice, achieving such goal is challenging, because of the sheer number of uncontrollable factors that influence customer responses. To address these challenges, academics and practitioners have developed and adopted a selection of analytical tools in the form of “marketing models”, which are crystallized from disciplines such as economics, statistics and computer science.

This course focuses on 1) how to translate managerial problems into analytical problems, and 2) how to solve these analytical problems with marketing models. In paricular, the course covers important marketing problems, such as how to successfully design and diffuse a new product, how to price a product or service to gain short-term profits and long-term equity, and how to build and manage heterogeneous and dynamic customer portfolios. The course adopts a hands-on approach, where you are expected to work on cases with actual data to solve real managerial problems. Overall, the course will show you how to understand, predict and influence customers using marketing models.

• To explain the principles of marketing modeling with real-world examples.
• To implement core marketing models (brand choice and demand models, customer segmentation, conjoint analysis, new product diffusion, and pricing) to solve managerial problems.
• To differentiate the three basic functions of marketing models (i.e., prediction, evaluation and optimization).
• To critically evaluate various marketing models, especially those new solutions.
• To translate managerial problems into analytical problems, which can be solved by marketing models.
• To develop solutions to managerial problems based on marketing models.

column1: Individuals or households can choose to respond or not to a direct mailing, or they can choose between various brands in the supermarket. This course deals with econometric models for these qualitative variables. Examples of these models are the logit and probit models for binomial data and multinomial logit models for multinomial data. Also, ordered data, like those evolving from questionnaires, and count data will be considered.
The focus of the course is on model representation, model interpretation, parameter estimation and diagnostics.

column1: The emphasis on this course is to use marketing research to aid to managerial decision making. Hence, we will focus our attention on the interpretation of statistical results in the applied aspects of various research techniques unique to marketing data. This is not a course on statistics and hence no attempt will be made to prove statistical theorems or derive mathematical solutions to statistical problems. However, this course builds heavily on prior knowledge on statistical methods and extends this to methods that are frequently used in marketing research. In particular, we will focus on ANOVA, linear regression models, choice models and factor analysis.

column1: Instructors: Prof. F. Sotgiu (VU) and Prof. J. Guyt (UvA)

This course offers an overview of the econometric, statistical and behavioral foundations in the field of marketing science. It covers several substantive topics and discusses state-of-the-art methods that academic and industry marketers can use to make sense of ubiquitous market and consumer-level data (big data), as well as several state-of-the-art techniques for primary data collection (thick data).

This course introduces students to the field of marketing science which serves all those professionals – academics or practitioners – who answer important research questions in marketing using mathematical modeling. As such, marketing science draws upon solid econometric and statistical foundations that are common to other business data sciences. For example, we will discuss state-of-the-art econometric models and predictive analytics that firms can use to better understand their customers and optimize their marketing decisions.

Marketing science goes beyond purely predictive models with the goal of understanding customer and firm behavior. Students will find that this emphasis on cause-and-effect makes the field exciting and inherently interdisciplinary. For instance, we will be discussing how to draw upon theories from different fields (e.g., marketing, economics, psychology, and sociology) to build better mathematical models capable of generating more valuable customer and market insights.

Another related distinction between marketing science and other data sciences fields is that it goes beyond big data (i.e., data with high volume, velocity and variety) and also emphasizes thick data (i.e., in-depth data about customer and firm behavior, typically gathered through experiments, surveys or even qualitative methods), as well as the combination of both. Hence, in marketing science the ability to design and interpret primary research is a must. We will be discussing how to design, gather and use primary data to complement and enrich insights garnered through secondary data. Following these topics, students will familiarize themselves with (amongst others):
1. The use of aggregate level methods to quantify the market responses to marketing mix changes
2. Introduction into individual level choice models to measure consumer responses to marketing mix changes
3. The use of machine learning in market response models
4. Individual level choice model with Bayesian model of consumer learning and knowledge generalization
5. The use customer response and choice models in multichannel setting with timedimension and multiple touchpoints/customer contact mediums (Panel Probit and Logit)
6. Model based customer segmentation: Latent Class Clustering and Regression models

column1: The purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders. This course will help you to develop an in-depth understanding of key frameworks, concepts, and paradigms in marketing strategy and, just as important, to develop skills in the application of this knowledge. We will focus on two strategic problems, competitive positioning and innovation, and on two substantive areas, sustainability and technology. At a general level, the basic goal of this course is to help you make the transition from student to marketing practitioner and thus support your own goal of becoming a successful marketing professional. During the course, you will train extensively your case solving skills both in class, during interactive case discussions, and individually, in the assignments and trial exams. Student participation during the interactive lectures and meaningful contributions to the case discussions are essential. To facilitate interaction, the group will be split into three sections for some of the classes. Students will be tested by means of an exam and written case assignments (both individual and group).

column1: Overall, the course intends to make you well-informed and critical users of quantitative marketing, by presenting the essential tools and processes that are needed to make data-driven decisions for marketing strategies. Specifically, this course introduces a set of quantitative marketing tools that are essential for marketing strategy research. Through the discussion and application of these tools, the course intends to develop your abilities to identify and apply the right methods to solve marketing strategy problems. During the course, you will be offered hands-on training in marketing analytics with real datasets. Moreover, with case discussion, you will learn how to identify opportunities to improve business performances with marketing analytics (i.e., “when to use”), and formulate unbiased understanding of analytical tools (i.e., “how to choose”).

column1: In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing Management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven handelen namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staan. Daarvoor bekijken we hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.

• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing;

• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden die illustratief zijn van marketing theorie of duiden op problemen met een marketingstrategie te identificeren, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.

column1: New products, which are also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. This is very problematic for companies, given the huge amount of money involved in the research and development of new products. The success or failure of a new product is determined by its ultimate acceptance in the market place. This raises the question which factors influence the acceptance and diffusion of new products in the market place? This question will be central in this course. The answer to this question provides marketing managers with information on how to effectively develop and launch new products.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption and diffusion of new products in the market place, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions. Attention will be paid to the consumer adoption decision process as well as to the new product adoption decisions by retailers, both in the domestic and the international market. The course challenges you to think critically about new products marketing. As such, routine learning of terms and concepts is not sufficient. You are prepared to take a marketing manager’s seat in managing new products across international markets.

• To gain insights into the retailers’ adoption decision process.
• To gain insights in the consumers’ adoption process.
• To gain insights in the new product diffusion process.
• To be able to forecast the success of a new product.

column1: This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

column1: <body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

column1: (For Dutch students, see below) Writing a master's thesis based on a student's own research is the central feature of the master's programme. The master's thesis enables students to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to scholarly debate of a particular subject according to academic standards.
The following are additional requirements that the master’s thesis must satisfy:
•   the research is based on a clearly formulated problem and research questions;
•   the research is grounded in theories and methodologies from the discipline, or theories and
methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
•   these theories and methodologies will be critically assessed in relation to the formulation of the problem;
•   previous research concerning the chosen theme will be specified, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
•   the literature, primary and secondary sources, and other information and data will be presented systematically and in relation to each other;
•   the thesis will consist of an introduction, various chapters in which the findings will be discussed, a conclusion, bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
•   the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
•   the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and, if
•   the thesis will be written in polished, accurate Dutch or English;
•   the thesis will consist of approximately 20.000 words (+/- 10 %), not counting the title page, table of

In de master thesis laten studenten zien dat zij op basis van eigen, oorspronkelijk onderzoek een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan het wetenschappelijke debat over een bepaald onderwerp uit het eigen vakgebied. Overige eisen die worden gesteld aan de master thesis zijn:
•   het onderzoek is gebaseerd op een helder geformuleerde probleemstelling en daaruit afgeleide
•   het onderzoek is gestoeld op theorieën en methoden uit het vakgebied, dan wel theorieën en methoden die voor dit specifieke onderwerp relevant zijn;
•   deze theorieën en methoden worden in de thesis besproken en beargumenteerd in relatie tot de probleemstelling;
•   eerder onderzoek rond het gekozen onderwerp wordt aangegeven, samengevat en besproken voorzover relevant voor het eigen onderzoek;
•   gebruikte literatuur, primaire en secundaire bronnen, overige gegevens en data worden systematisch gepresenteerd en aan elkaar gerelateerd;
•   de thesis bestaat uit een inleiding, diverse hoofdstukken waarin de bevindingen worden besproken, conclusie, literatuurlijst en (eventueel) bijlagen;

•   de thesis is geschreven in verzorgd en accuraat Nederlands of Engels;
