<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:

column2: • the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions;
• the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme;
• the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
• the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated;
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.

column1: The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:

column2: • the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s); a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s); an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis; a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic;
• the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices;
• the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words;
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
• the article will be written in polished, accurate English;
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.

column1: Students have developed the knowlegde and skills to:​

column2: • Formulate an original and relevant scholarly problem in his or her field of study
• Draw up an appropriate research proposal, including a positioning of the thesis in currently scholarly discussion, a well-argued research strategy, and time plan
• Organize the research set-up (empirical and/or fieldwork research)
• Use current social-scientific methods and techniques to collect and analyze the required information and data
• Report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way
• Evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process
• Write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal

column1: In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a  well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students will develop a plan for their Master Thesis in the form of a research proposal. They will do so through consecutive assignments, where there is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, regular meetings serve as collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In doing so, ample attention is paid to content-related matters and designing a suitable method, as well as the time planning and formal criteria, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements. Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.

column1: First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfill as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between tourism, culture and society that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design. Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

In order to complete the Master of HEPL, with specialisation Health Economics, students are required to write a scientific Master thesis on a topic that is related to one of the subjects covered in the HEPL Master. The combined workload of the Thesis Plan and Thesis is 16 ECTS (or 448 hours) and thus constitutes a major part of the curriculum. Students write their Master thesis under supervision of a member of the HEPL staff. The evaluation of the thesis and defence for the final grade is conducted by the student's thesis reading committee, which includes the supervisor and one co-evaluator. The co-evaluator must be someone from the ESHPM or ESE staff.
More information regarding the HE thesis, the graduation procedure, and a link to the coursebook can be found at https://www.eur.nl/ese/english/information_for/students/master_students/master_

column1: : This course has two main objectives, i.e.to train students in essential academic skills and to guide them towards their MA-thesis: Firstly, students get the opportunity to learn, train and improve a number of essential academic skills. They are introduced and trained in techniques of argumentation and reasoning. Essential basics of academic writing, such as citation techniques, are rehearsed and students are introduced to the skills of philosophical writing. Last but certainly not least, students get the opportunity to train and improve their presentation skills.

Secondly, students are guided towards their MA-thesis in a milestone-process. In this process they learn how to choose a suitable topic for their thesis before they proceed in specifying a tractable research question. In a next step, students are guided in further developing their question into a thesis outline. They present their outline to their peers in order to receive first feedback before embarking on the process of writing their thesis in block 4. </body>

column1: The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master's thesis website.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

• Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

column1: Your thesis is the ‘masterpiece’ of your master’s degree in Sociology. The master’s thesis is an empirical study demonstrating that you have all the necessary competences to independently formulate sociologically relevant research questions, to select and apply suitable theoretical frameworks and methodological approaches consistent with the disciplinary and legal norms relating to privacy and ethics, and to communicate your work in a scientific and professional manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>In the process of writing your master’s thesis proposal, conducting the research necessary to answer your research question(s), and reporting on the study conducted in your master’s thesis, you will learn:

column2: • To formulate a suitable and sociologically relevant problem statement;
• To provide an overview of the extant literature in the chosen research subfield, resulting in a detailed and specific research question(s);
• To differentiate between descriptive and explanatory research questions;
• To use sociological theory and empirical findings to develop hypotheses and/or sub-questions, which constitute the basis for your theoretical framework;
• To create an appropriate research design to answer your research question(s);
• To assess the feasibility of your research design;
• To demonstrate and document the proper, careful consideration of the ethics and privacy implications of your study;
• To reliably operationalize the core concepts of your study;
• To independently conduct empirical research using secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using suitable analytical methods and techniques;
• To discuss the theoretical and empirical value of your study and evaluate your study’s sociological and societal relevance;
• To clearly and adequately orally communicate your thesis proposal to both expert and lay audiences.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>A sufficient assessment of the thesis proposal is the condition for being able to start carrying out the thesis research.</body>

A Albareda Sanz', 'dr. L Ripoll Gonzalez', 'dr. WAH Spekkink', 'dr.ir. J Eshuis', 'prof.dr. DA McCauley', 'prof.dr. JFM Koppenjan']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the MGN courses and topics. The thesis must  have an a recognizible  governance topic as research object and focused on analyzing this governance topic

Note that an internship is not part of the MGN program (but in special cases it is possible to include this. But this always needs a positive decision of the supervisors of the master program). .At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, who will very often be one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the MGN program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors. After the manuscript has been approved by the supervisor, he or she will involve a second reader. When both approve the research project and all requirements of the MGN master have been satisfied, the thesis will be defended in front of the delegated examination board.</body>

•        to operationalize concepts into reliable and valid indicators;
•        to choose and defend appropriate methods of data collection and to actually collect relevant and reliable data;
•        to choose and defend appropriate methods of data analysis and to analyze data systematically;
•        to reflect on the conclusion in terms of limitations, theoretical and/or practical implications, and the need for further research;
•        to clearly structure and fully reference a research report.

column1: Students attending the Master Class will get familiarized with the complexity of the actual financial/insurance world and will be able to understand this and to form their own opinion. Lectures will be presented by specialists from Allianz Benelux and speakers from other leading organisations. This combination will guarantee quality and independency of the course. Each lecture contains a practical part in the form of a case or small assignment. Attending the Master Class will reward students with a certificate provided by the Erasmus School of Economics.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This extracurricular Master Class is organized in cooperation with Allianz. It is meant for students who want to know more about an interesting and dynamic discipline: actuarial sciences. Actuaries are experts in analysing the past, modelling the future, assessing the risk involved by using mathematical and statistical models and communicating what the result means in financial terms. In the Master Class the most important aspects of the actuarial profession will be presented by bringing together theory and practice.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het vak Masterclasses wordt verzorgd door de partners die verbonden zijn aan Toga aan de Maas. Er wordt gewerkt met drie lijnen binnen het vak Masterclasses: (i) Togavaardigheden, (ii) Verdieping/inhoudelijk en (iii) Soft skills. Binnen de lijn Togavaardigheden leren de studenten een juridische procedure te doorlopen. Onder andere de volgende onderwerpen komen hier aan bod: het eerste contact met cliënten, het analyseren van een dossier en procesadvies, schriftelijke stukken opstellen, processtrategie, comparitie van partijen en pleiten, vonnis schrijven, hoger beroep en cassatie. Ook alternatieve geschilbeslechting komt binnen deze lijn aan bod. Binnen de lijn Verdieping/inhoudelijk worden belangrijke juridische leerstukken en actuele onderwerpen besproken. Tot slot, staat de lijn Soft skills in het teken van de persoonlijke ontwikkeling van studenten, met onderwerpen als legal English, personal branding, presenteren/pitchen, onderhandelen en stress management. De diverse masterclasses vinden plaats bij de partnerkantoren, bestaande uit advocatenkantoren, het Openbaar Ministerie en de rechtspraak.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• De student kan zelfstandig een juridisch vraagstuk oplossen, bijbehorend onderzoek verrichten (in de papieren en digitale bronnen zelfstandig gevonden informatie op correcte wijze analyseren en beoordelen om deze vervolgens toe te passen en te verwerken) en daarvan verslag doen.
• De student kan in samenwerking oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex probleem en kan binnen die samenwerking een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.
• De student kan rekening houden met de invloed van verschillende rechtsgebieden en het vraagstuk in bredere context plaatsen.

• De student beheerst zowel de schriftelijke als de mondelinge togavaardigheden, dus kan onder andere (juridische) adviezen, memoranda, brieven en processtukken schrijven, alsook cliëntgesprekken voeren, getuigenverhoren afnemen, onderhandelen en pleidooi houden.

• De student is op de hoogte van actualiteiten in verschillende rechtsgebieden en begrijpt de maatschappelijke en juridische relevantie van de betreffende actualiteit in relatie tot de wereld van het recht.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101221,2021,Masterclass actualiteiten gezondheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak wordt het onderwijs primair verzorgd door gerenommeerde juristen (advocaten, ziekenhuisjuristen, etc.) werkzaam in de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht. Zij laten de studenten kennismaken met actuele ontwikkelingen op de verschillende deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied: het zorgverleningsrecht, het zorgverzekeringsrecht en het zorginkooprecht. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd hun eerder opgedane kennis van deze deelgebieden van het gezondheidsrecht toe te passen op actuele vraagstukken. De studenten krijgen van de gastdocenten casuïstiek voorgelegd, die zij moeten behandelen in wekelijks in te leveren werkstukken. De rechtsvragen die de studenten krijgen voorgelegd, zijn ontleend aan die van de rechtspraktijk van de gastdocenten. Het onderwijs vindt deels plaats ten kantore van de praktijkjuristen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Doel/Purpose:

• De student heeft kennisgemaakt met de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht en de laatste ontwikkelingen op alle deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied. Hij heeft weet van de relevante rechtspraak en nieuwe ontwikkelingen op deze terreinen en is in staat om deze ontwikkelingen te kunnen plaatsen en op hun relevantie te kunnen beoordelen.

• De student beschikt over juridische en algemene academische vaardigheden, waarbij kennis van het gezondheidsrecht, inzicht en probleemoplossende vermogens kunnen worden toegepast in nieuwe of onbekende omstandigheden binnen de bredere (of multidisciplinaire) context van dit rechtsgebied.
• Dit betekent dat
• de student wet- en regelgeving op casuïstiek kan toepassen en een logisch antwoord kan formuleren op de rechtsvragen bij een casus.
• de student op basis van een actuele casus de rechtsvraag kan formuleren;
• De student geeft bij het doen van de praktijkopdrachten blijk van creativiteit en zelfstandigheid.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100673,2021,Mastering Networks for Innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Tasselli'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Social network connections and positions constrain and facilitate outcomes of importance to individuals, groups, and organizations. For instance, Networks and relationships are not only critical to access and exchange information and resources but also imperative to organize support and to market innovative ideas.

In the lectures of this course we focus on social networks and relationships more generally and on when and how they influence innovation in particular. We address different network structures (e.g., size, tie strength, centrality, or density) across different levels (e.g., individual-, dyadic-, team-, or organizational-level) in different innovation phases (e.g., idea generation, implementation, or diffusion). Furthermore, we discuss important differences between online and offline social networks and explore the general drivers and antecedents of social networks and relationships.
In workshops you get familiar with the UCINET and NetDraw software. These are tools that help you analyze and visualize social networks.

In a project that is run in co-operation with an organization, you will apply the insights of this course to craft a strategy that utilizes the power of social networks and you will give advice on how the network should and could be developed in the future.

The learnings of this course are especially relevant for prospective consultants and innovation managers who need to analyze and shape change processes and intra- or inter-organizational collaboration projects. For students interested in examining, understanding, and optimizing their network position and structure, the learnings are of equal use.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
You will get equipped with the latest insights and theories on the drivers and consequences of social networks for innovation.
<li>
You will learn state-of-the-art tools to analyse and visualize social networks.
• You will understand the advantages and disadvantages that certain positions in a network have.
• You will be able to give advice about the changes that are necessary to take full advantage of a network position.

• Studenten leren een relevante onderzoeksvraag te formuleren op het terrein van het zelfgekozen fiscale of fiscaal-economische onderwerp.

column1: Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Na dit vak kan de student:

column2: • De beginselen, systematiek en wetsbepalingen van het materiele strafrecht herkennen, analyseren en toepassen op een materieelstrafrechtelijke casus;
• De betekenis en functie van legaliteit begrijpen;
• De betekenis en functie van wederrechtelijkheid begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en bewijsvormen van opzet herkennen, begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en bewijsvormen van culpa herkennen, begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis van causaliteit begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en het systeem van strafuitsluitingsgronden en culpa in causa begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en het systeem van poging, voorbereiding en vrijwillige terugtred begrijpen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis en functie van ne bis in idem en samenloop begrijpen en het onderscheid tussen deze leerstukken herkennen en toepassen op een casus;
• De betekenis van de verschillende deelnemingsvormen begrijpen en het onderscheid tussen de vormen medeplegen en medeplichtigheid herkennen en toepassen op een casus;
• Het systeem en de strafbaarheid van privaatrechtelijke en publiekrechtelijke rechtspersonen begrijpen en toepassen op een casus.
• De relevante jurisprudentie toepassen, analyseren en in onderling verband kritisch  beoordelen  mede  in  het licht  van  de  relevante  materieelrechtelijke beginselen.

column1: The course focuses on the strategic analysis of markets and contracts under asymmetric information. It does so by using Game Theory in a mathematical, rigorous way.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The goal of the course is twofold. First, to show how mathematics can be used to formulate and investigate economic phenomena. Second, to make students familiar with important contributions to the analysis of markets and contracts under asymmetric information.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99240,2021,Mathematical Economics (old),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. V Karamychev'],,Inhoud

The course consists of two parts. It begins with a refreshment on classical microeconomics analysis and develops into the utility maximization theory, in Part 1. The necessary mathematical tools (ODE) are briefly presented. The main analytical emphasis is on restoring underlying preferences from empirically observed individual behavior.

In the second, large part, the course begins with a brief introduction to Game theory and develops into the area of Bayesian games. A few examples from the recent economic literature are studied in depth.

column2: • To know deep functional dependencies between underlying individual preferences and empirically observed economic behaviour.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of strategic interaction.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of private information.
• To be able to formulate the problem of recovering preferences from behavior, and to solve its simple instances.
• To be able to compute different kinds of equilibria for different types of games.
• In general, to be able to use mathematical tools for relating behavior to the underlying economic model.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This Mathematics course presents the necessary Mathematical tools for analysing quantitative models that emerge from a variety of business and economic problems. The selection below reflects the scope of the studied Mathematical topics that will be useful for the analysis of economics and business problems. These topics are:

column2: • Functions and equations of one and two variables
• Sequences and series
• Financial applications
• Differentiation and optimization
• Integration
• Matrices

column1: This course lays the foundation for the quantitative courses to follow in the IBA curriculum. The scientific description and analysis of complex practical business situations often requires an analytic approach. What is usually needed is the explicit description of the transition of a system when it moves from one state to the next. Mathematics is well equipped to assist in the difficult task of describing the essential elements of such transitions. The word ""model"" is often used for the quantitative description of the specific problem in which a system finds itself at any moment in time. Working with models is a recurring activity in business studies. The process of building and analysing business models requires a Mathematical way of thinking. Therefore, mathematical skills are essential for successfully handling these business models.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: The concepts, skills, and methods from the ‘Preparation course mathematics’ are a prerequisite for this course. You will not be able to understand the course without having successfully mastered the learning goals of the preparation course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing this course, students will be able to apply the mathematical techniques covered in this course and to build, analyze and solve mathematical models emerging from business problems using mathematical techniques from the course and interpret the solutions in terms of the original problem. A detailed list of learning goals per learning unit is available in the document ‘Material overview’ in the ‘Course Information’ on Canvas.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course is based on online modules, which provide the theory and practice exercises. Each week, optional question hours are scheduled where you can ask questions about the material. There is a midterm and final exam. This set-up offers a high flexibility (no lectures or tutorials), and relies primarily on self-study. This version of the course is intended for students that have a considerable proficiency in mathematics.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course, students will

column2: • Have acquired mathematical skills that support more quantitative courses in EUC

• Be able to deal with mathematics in such a way that in later years a student will be able to recognize which subject from mathematics is used and – if necessary – to study more advanced topics by her/himself.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This is a crash course, highlighting the main principles of measure theory and asymptotic methods in statistics.
Part I: Sigma-algebras, measure, integration w.r.t. a measure, limit theorems, product measure and integration, change of measure, conditional expectation.
Part II: Multivariate central limit theorem, quadratic forms, delta-method, moment estimators, Z-and M-estimators, consistency and asymptotic normality, maximum likelihood estimators.

J Veldwijk', 'dr. MF Jonker', 'NVR Smeele, MSc', 'prof.dr. EW de Bekker - Grob', 'SFW Himmler']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences for health care products and programs are also shaped by non-health outcomes (such as amount of information) and process attributes (such as treatment location, or route of drug administration). Studies into these outcomes beyond health are an emerging trend in HTA and health economics. Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCE allows investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit, which gives this method the flexibility to include any concern deemed of relevance. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory underlying DCEs, demonstrate the process of carrying out a choice study, and discuss the policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and work groups, but students will also be actively involved in a DCE study with the aim to increase understanding of what is taught. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The groups complete their work step by step over several weeks. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE; individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.
The written examination is 70% of the final grade (minimum grade 5.0 or higher). The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%) and a group project (30%).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • recognize the importance of patient preference measurements in health care
• describe the theoretical foundation(s) of discrete choice experiments (DCEs)
• develop their own DCE using state-of-the-art (publishable) methods
• understand recent articles in the DCE literature and assess the validity of the presented conclusions

column1: <body>Understanding ‘the audience’ has long been a central concern in the fields of communication and media studies. This course offers a critical survey of academic research exploring the relationships between audiences and media technologies/texts. A variety of interdisciplinary perspectives will be addressed including active audience theory, spectatorship, media effects, uses and gratifications, critical/cultural studies, and fans/fandom. The literature used in this course applies these perspectives to a variety of media content/forms including television, cinema, videogames, and streaming video.</body>

column1: <body>This seminar addresses the theory and practice of media campaigns as well as processes that drive the planning and execution of these campaigns and the role of the latest technological advancements in campaigning. Students will review theories and research on segmentation, media use and persuasion and will analyze real-world media campaigns by drawing on the theoretical and research articles covered in the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on media campaigns
• The role and use of (different) media in various types of campaigns.
• The complexities of persuasion within media campaigns.
• Cultural dimensions of media campaigns in different countries and social backgrounds.
• Explain the major components of media campaigns, the primary outcome variables, and the individual difference and social psychological variable associated with message receivers.
• Analyze and critique the effectiveness of media campaigns within a business, health, or political context.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100182,2021,Media Economics and Media Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. V Chaudhri', 'PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In media studies, research tends to focus on the output of media industries. In this course, we take another perspective by investigating the economic characteristics of media markets and the strategic behavior of media firms on them. How did Facebook come to dominate the social media market? How are incumbent TV broadcasters responding to the challenges posed by Youtube and Netflix? In order to study these and other questions, we will address key media economic theoretical traditions, learn how to define markets, discuss the particular characteristics of media products and investigate the fast changes in media. After this, we will use media management literature to understand how media firms are responding to economic structures, product characteristics and market changes.  We will take an explicit international perspective, using case studies from many different parts of the world. In these case studies, we will study how the specific economic characteristics of the media product and societal and economic context within it is offered, affected the strategic management decisions that were made. Students are also required to conduct a case study themselves of a media firm’s behavior in its defined market.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Major theoretical perspectives and key concepts in media economics.
• Current perspectives on the strategic management of media companies and the impact of external pressures (market, regulation, globalization etc.) on media firms' strategies.
• Analyze media products, media firms and media markets from an economic for-profit perspective.
• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media firms and their products.
• Formulate the implications of media economic analyses for strategic management decisions of media firms.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100224,2021,Media Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. HJCJ Hitters', 'dr. S Horst']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Comprehend current concepts, approaches and theories of entrepreneurship for working in media organizations and mediated contexts;
• Discuss and evaluate the importance of entrepreneurship around media and media organizations;
• Analyze how media organizations and practitioners manage entrepreneurship and behave in entrepreneurial manner.
• Identify needs, opportunities and challenges for entrepreneurial actions in media and creative industries;
• Construct and develop responses for tackling issues in creative entrepreneurial manner;
• Synthesize and evaluate entrepreneurial actions in relations to current theoretical frameworks;
• Demonstrate the conduct of a qualitative interview with an entrepreneur.

column1: This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.
Note:You can not take this course combined with Media Industries and Audiences: CM0004 (the content is the same)
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • The main theoretical approaches and perspectives to the study of mass mediated communication in historical perspective
• Key concepts and approaches to the study of media contents, media production, media reception, media uses and media influences
• Influences on media contents; global and local processes of media production,distribution and reception; uses and influences of media

column1: Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of mass mediated communication
• Take an international, comparative perspective to media processes and influences
• Articulate and develop their own viewpoints and research questions,using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings
• Communicate their viewpoints and research questions clearly and effectively, both orally and in writing

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100137,2021,Media Industries: Trends and Strategies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts, approaches, developments, trends, problems and governance in theory and empirics of media industries and media innovation,
• Key analytical tools to define and study media industries
• Key analytical tools to define and study media innovation
• Reflect critically on the theoretical viewpoints and research materials presented in class
• Critically reflect upon developments in media industries and assess their impact and newness.
• Analyse current developments and strategies in the media industries using theories and concepts covered in the course

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100219,2021,Media Policies and Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. HJCJ Hitters', 'dr. I Awad Cherit', 'dr. V Chaudhri', 'PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Governments have always had a special interest in media markets. Their policies and regulation can have a great impact on the boundaries within which media organizations can operate. Governmental scrutiny of media is often justified by societal expectations that countries have of their media sector. The fast-paced changes in the media industry have forced governments around the world to reassess their media policy. For instance, the scandal around Cambridge Analytica’s usage of Facebook users’ data has forced many governments to rethink their privacy regulations.

During this course, we will use models from (media) economics and institutional economics to conceptualize the interplay between government policy and media markets. In addition, we will focus on theories and developments around policy and regulation that allow us to analyze, critically assess and contextualize media policy.

The seminar connects relevant issues within media policy to relevant theoretical concepts. From examples on fake news to hate speech and violation of data privacy. We will discuss these and other developments in media policy using practical and international examples. Furthermore, we will try to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have taken. The seminar is participative in nature, which means that students are required to prepare the lecture, participate in discussions, debate and give presentations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the interplay between media markets, media firms and governmental policy
• relevant theories to analyze media policy
• the most important international developments in media policy for media markets (e.g. privacy, copyrights, market power, freedom of speech)
• global differences in media policy traditions
• analyse media policy
• reflect critically on relevant theory and developments in media policy
• analyse and critically evaluate different policy options
• assess the impact of governmental policy on media markets

column1: <body>This course introduces students with major theoretical perspectives and methodological approaches in the comparative study of media systems and media industries. The course offers a wide-ranging survey of media systems across different regions of the world. Students will be familiarized with comparative research, addressing the economic, social, political, regulatory and cultural aspects of media systems. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework.</body>

• Principal dimensions of variation in media systems and the complex of forces shaping their evolution.
• Analyze and reflect upon over time changes and cross-national differences in media systems and media industries;

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia that allow customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This new platform economy creates new questions regarding how algorithms shape the competitiveness of the travel and tourism industry and to what extent does this allow for a level playing field for companies in this sector. Further, the rise of the middle class in countries like India and China are producing new user groups that pushes tourism-related companies to rethink their advertising, city branding and packaging strategies that can best tailor to these new demographics.

In fact, across industries we see disruptions taking place with the rise of digital media, novel technologies and platforms, new data policies, governance measures, and new user groups. These trends demand that we reflect and rethink the ways in which these industries are being transformed and the repercussions on the future of work and wellbeing for our societies. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the  birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy where certain intermediaries have become digital.

This course will focus on case studies from diverse sectors including healthcare, marketing, and education and how the data economies are manifesting within these specific industries. Students will explore the global and political infrastructures at play as technology companies, laborers, user groups, and governance structures span across nations, complicating our understandings of a typical business today. We will jointly explore urgent ethical challenges, serious sustainability concerns, and dominant global trends in user behaviors, company practices, and national policies that pushes for a design thinking approach to “good” organizational practice.

Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical perspective on the role of digital media and datafication in different industries  in order to shape more inclusive, ethical and sustainable business models and practices in this digital and global age.

column2: <title></title>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100099,2021,Media and Communication Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AE Mols', 'dr. AJC van der Hoeven', 'dr. ML Wayne', 'dr. RA Harder', 'P Mashigo, MA']",,"Inhoud

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.
Note:You can not take this course combined with Media Industries and Audiences: CM1012 (the content is the same)

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
· Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of consumer culture
· The history and commercial and social aspects of advertising
· Integrate knowledge gained from specific topics and integrate this in a focus written report
· Apply a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and critically reflect on the advertising industry’s influence on society
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98566,2021,Media and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. EH Klijn'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: Being able to explain the most important theories on mass communication and the functioning of the media, also in relation to branding
Explaining what relevant developments are in the relation between media, public administration and society
Analyzing different aspects of these developments by using concrete examples.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100201,2021,Media and Migration,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. A Paz Alencar', 'dr. I Awad Cherit']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to either escape harsh lives, search for better ones, or both. Continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in many societies have led to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of so-called transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as multiple embeddings of migrants in their (new) homelands. In this course,  we  focus on  the  critical  role  played by media  and communication  in  the  different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in digital spaces, from interactions between relevant stakeholders in the field of NGOs and policy-making through the political and economic side of migrants’ lives to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

This course aims to offer a platform for students to develop their research skills for making sense of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (Western and non-Western) and drivers of migration (e.g., economic, political, cultural, humanitarian, environmental). In eight weeks, students will work on their own research project, covering topics related to migration, media and technology. Research projects involve using theories and empirical analyses based on in-depth interview research, contacting migration actors, practicing intercultural skills training for conducting research and/or working in this field, among others. Throughout this process, students will gain conceptual, empirical and practical knowledge for their master thesis projects.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The research workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing theoretical, empirical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and key concepts in the study of media and migration.
• Qualitative methodologies in research on media and migration.
• Ethical issues and procedures in research involving migrant populations.
• The experiences of migrants in relation to communication practices and networks that involve digital media.
• Design and execute a small-scale in-depth interview study on the topic of migrants and the media.
• Report and present their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100125,2021,Media and Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. DD Dumitrica', 'dr. RA Harder']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicians and other public figures try to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of democratic values. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products, approaching them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100196,2021,Media and Social-Cultural Change,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. I Awad Cherit'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio-cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles can people - activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example - play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions. It looks for answers in the academic literature, as well as in students' own identification and observation of contemporary cases. Theoretically, the course relies on communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. Special attention is paid, for example, to ideology and hegemony, (journalistic) objectivity, mediatization, media/technological determinism, structure and agency.
Since the relationship between the media and socio-cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course adopts a historical and cross-national perspective.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Different ways in which media stimulate or hinder socio-cultural change.
• Diverse academic perspectives towards media and social-cultural change and key theoretical concepts therein.
• How current socio-political and technological developments are affecting the media’s role in relation to social change.
• Contemporary strategies used and related challenges faced by actors using the media for and against social change.
• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
• Take and defend theoretical positions.
• Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and in their own work.

column1: In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bijzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing en crowdfunding passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein;
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen;
• De maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100148,2021,Media in Latin-America,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media. It strives to provide with a panorama of what is happening across the continent and examine the role of media in politics, and its relationship to national identity and state building. The sessions will discuss on a country basis; the build-up of national media production and the flow of media, into, across and out of Latin America; as well as the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America. Theoretically, we will examine approaches that have originated in Latin America: hybridity, dependency, imperialism, globalization, as well as, the development of geo-cultural and cultural- linguistic regions. An element of this course will include watching and discussing media from the region, as well as evaluations made in and outside the region. Specialists from different areas of the region will provide lectures in order to explore more closely the link among the media formats, contents and the changing social realities in the Latin-American region.</body>

</style>

column1: <body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media, including the role it plays in politics and its relationship to national identity and state building. It will cover the build-up of national media production and the flow of media into, across and out of Latin America; the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: <body>This course focuses on children's media use and on parents and educators who raise their children to media-literate persons. The child's media-landscape will be discussed together with theories on how the media may influence children. Next the role of parents will be discussed. Parents can use various strategies to further positive media effects such as learning, or dampen negative effects such as fear reactions or aggression. Students will be stimulated to explore and think about their own experiences and ideas on the strategies that parents use with traditional media as television and  cinema movies, and with modern media such as computers, game consoles, smart phones, and tablets. Furthermore, we will look at tools that exist for parents, such as rating systems (Kijkwijzer and PEGI), technical safety applications on the computer, and several information and advice sources,  such as Common Sense Media. The final goal of this course is a to propose a practical tool for supporting parents in guiding their children’s media use.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Different academic perspectives on parents' mediation of their children’s media use.
• The contemporary children's media landscape.
• How and why parents guide their children's media consumption; parenting support tools, such as rating systems.
• Critically reflect upon different academic perspectives and theories on parental mediation.
• Independently apply these in their own writings and (desk)research.
• Present their ideas on parental mediation to an audience of fellow students.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100195,2021,Media, Culture and Globalisation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AJC van der Hoeven', 'dr. I Awad Cherit', 'P Mashigo, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course focuses on the key role of the media and cultural industries in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past decades witnessed a significant intensification of international cultural flows. Among other reasons, this is a consequence of the introduction of new media technologies and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalisation in the media and cultural industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as global cities, multiculturalism, global media events and cosmopolitanism. Both the meetings and the assignments will pay ample attention to the future of globalisation. We will use scenario-building techniques to explore the future connections between media, culture and globalisation. In these activities, theories about globalisation will be applied to societal and organisational problems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100937,2021,Mediation advocacy: theory and practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104525,2021,"Mediation, Moderation, and Conditional Process Modeling",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Evangelidis'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Mediation topics include: 1) simple mediation with any type of independent and dependent variables (i.e., continuous, dichotomous, multicategorical), 2) mediation with multiple parallel mediators, 3) mediation with multiple serial mediators. Moderation topics include: 1) moderation models with up to 2 moderators (3-way interactions) using any type of independent and dependent variables, 2) analysis of unconditional versus conditional effects, 3) Model estimation and interpretation, 4) Visualization. I will also discuss how to analyze conditional process models (i.e., models that include both mediation and moderation). Depending on the pace of the course I will also try to cover some specialized topics such as mediation analysis in within-participants designs and mediation analysis using a binary mediator. The course will be focused on teaching you how to conduct the appropriate analysis and interpret your results. We will be using PROCESS (Hayes, 2018) for the purposes of this course. Attendants should have a recent version of SPSS or R installed on their computer.
This course is taught by Dr Ioannis Evangelidis (ESADE Business School, Ramon Llull University).</body>

column1: In this course you will learn how to conduct and interpret the results of mediation, moderation, and conditional process analyses. Mediation describes the case where an independent variable X influences another variable M (mediator), which in turn influences the dependent variable Y. Moderation describes the case where the effect of the independent variable X on the dependent variable Y changes across different levels of another variable M (moderator). Conditional process models combine mediation with moderation. This is an applied course: knowledge of algebra is not required. However, a basic understanding of OLS regression is necessary. This course is targeted to any person doing social science research that wants to learn how to test for mediation and moderation in his or her data.

<body>Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? When should doctors refuse requests for new technologies of assisted reproduction, such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF)? Do we have a moral duty to fund orphan drugs? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity or organ donation? Are new technologies to enhance the capabilities of human beings (such as cognition, social behaviour and mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Are patients with diverse cultural and ethnical background treated equally in the clinic?  Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this course, we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. In the first part of the course, the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent) will be introduced. In the second part of the course, the obtained knowledge will be applied to issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.</body>
