analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates;
to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate;
argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments;
evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

column1: This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays an essential role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have severe memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.

• a basic understanding of some important mathematical models of human memory; and
• basic skills needed to critically evaluate claims in research papers.

column1: Corporate takeovers are one of the most important corporate events. Furthermore, during the takeover process firms encounter several challenges, such as legal, cultural, and regulatory hurdles. Overall, the argument to take over another firm must be very compelling. However, takeovers intensify agency problems between the stakeholders, most importantly between the management and the shareholders. This course focuses on the role of corporate governance with special emphasis on the context of takeovers or mergers and acquisitions (M&A).

The goal of this course is to provide students with a general understanding of corporate governance mechanisms within the firm. It also highlights the importance of corporate governance in the context of M&As. Furthermore, the course combines theory, empirical evidence, and practitioners’ views on topics at the intersection of accounting, M&A, and corporate governance. Guest lectures throughout the course provide students with the unique opportunity to gain insights from and engage in discussions with specialists from the field.

After participating in this course we hope that you improve your decision making by recognizing that corporate governance plays a crucial part in takeover activities as well as in the functioning of the firm by reducing agency conflicts stemming from the separation of ownership and control.

column1: ​On completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Explain and understand the firm’s corporate governance structure
• Be aware of how corporate governance can affect management behaviour
• Understand how corporate governance plays a role in M&As
• Apply basic concepts of accounting and valuation within the context of M&As
• Have gained insights into selected topics (guest lectures) from specialists in the field of M&A, accounting and corporate governance

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98918,2021,Mergers and Acquisitions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Mulder', 'dr. S van Kampen']",,"Inhoud

Since the late 1990s and until the burst of the 2008–09 global financial crisis, we have witnessed a dramatic increase in both domestic and international mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in Europe, the U.S. and in the rest of the world. Corporate finance theory suggests that takeovers and corporate restructuring can serve as an effective strategic tool for companies to respond to changes in the economic environment and, thus, create value for their shareholders. This course deals with mergers, acquisitions and other corporate restructuring activities in an international context. The course concentrates on the motives and strategic aspects of takeovers and restructuring, the valuation of firms involved in takeovers, the role of agency conflicts (between the management and the shareholders of a corporation) in takeovers, the effect of takeovers and restructuring on shareholder value and the practical aspects of the takeover process. It introduces the key principles and techniques of successful mergers, acquisitions, divestitures and leveraged buyouts. Next to taking a purely financial view, the course also looks at the psychological aspects of corporate restructuring transactions. For example, it has been shown that a lot of managers take over other firms simply because they are too confident about the value of the target, or because they want to boost their ego. The course discusses academic articles as well as anecdotal evidence about these irrational elements in M&A activity. Moreover, it discusses the impact of the 2008–2009 financial crisis on M&A and corporate restructuring activities throughout the world.

This course addresses such crucial questions as: Why do takeover deals that looked great on paper fail in reality? How does one value companies acquiring, or being acquired? What is the best negotiation strategy? How can one properly manage risks when designing a deal? What does it take to make the “synergy” come to life? When do leveraged buy-outs make sense, and how can they be financed?

column1: This course is intended to enhance the M&A preparedness of students in their future roles as employees, M&A advisors, or stakeholders by providing an overview of topics relating to M&A.  The course will combine theory with practical insights from invited guest speakers.  The theoretical content will be focused on the institutional settings that underlie M&A transactions and their implications for various deal-related choices.  We will use findings from extant academic literature to highlight stylized facts about M&A.

The course will cover the following broad themes: (i) drivers of mergers and takeovers and sources of value creation from M&A, (ii) considerations underlying deal structuring, payment and financing choices, and (iii) accounting challenges, valuation and risk management in the context of M&A.

column1: This course introduces framing theory and discusses its relevance for media and communication studies. The seminars focus on framing theory and discuss practical challenges in message framing and persuasion.

This course teaches students how organisations (private and public), the news media, and audiences interact through public relations and how communication professionals strategically frame their messages. This has a theoretical and a practical dimension. In the theoretical part, students learn what framing in the media is: The modern public sphere builds on dynamic media technologies and complex networks of media- and communication organisations. Audiences learn about current issues and important developments in business, culture, and society through different types of media. Modern communications and PR professionals need to understand the complex interplay of content (language and visuals), technology (channels and formats) and relationships between relevant stakeholders (the target audience, key media outlets, and other organisations) that underlie and shape framing processes. A successful combination of content, technology, and relationships with media organisations can make a profound impact on how audiences perceive a particular message, i.e., pick up on its framing.

Understanding this process eventually enables communication experts to design and execute effective campaigns that build up, reinforce, enhance, or repair an organization’s public reputation. Practical use cases include e.g., product/campaign launches, policy implementations, or crisis management. In the practice-oriented part of the course, students learn how to frame issues through strategic communication in written and spoken word, using modern technology (mainly via a press kit and press conference).

Public and private organisations are often at the center of news reporting in diverse contexts. It is essential for communication professionals to have in-depth knowledge about how public communication and framing in the media work in a digital society, so that they can represent their organisation strategically and result oriented.</body>

column1: De cursus omvat twee luiken die op elkaar afgestemd worden: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik.

In het logische luik bestuderen we de predicatenlogica. We beschouwen dan ook redeneringen waarvan de correctheid niet alleen steunt op de betekenis van de voegtekens maar ook op de betekenis van de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"". We onderscheiden het semantische begrip “geldig gevolg van” en het syntactische begrip “afleidbaar uit” en bestuderen de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen.

In het systematische luik worden de centrale problemen uit formele ontologie en de analytische metafysica aan de orde gesteld: universalia, substanties, tijd, compositie, persistentie, causaliteit, responsafhankelijkheid en wereldbeelden.

Studenten mogen één werkcollege missen. Indien ze meerdere werkcolleges missen, moeten er ter compensatie opgaven gemaakt worden die bij het (de) gemiste werkcollege(s) horen en welke beoordeeld worden. Het tentamenonderdeel dat overeenkomt met de gemiste werkcolleges zal beoordeeld worden met het laagste cijfer behaald voor (i) de compenserende opgaven (ii) de tentamenopgaven behorende bij de gemiste werkcolleges.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: 1.. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de predicaten logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de predicaten logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Tarski’s waarheidsdefinitie voor de taal van de predicaten logica en gerelateerde noties zoals model, vervulbaarheid, vrije en gebonden variabele en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze noties, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

3.  De student is vertrouwd met een tableau (afleidings-) systeem voor de predicatenlogica en in staat om dit systeem  te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

4. De student is vertrouwd met enkele toepassingen van (het modelbegrip uit) de predicaten logica in de analytische filosofie, met name in de analytische metafysica, en in staat om zich hier kritisch tot te verhouden.
5. De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende ontische, ontologische en metafysische onderwerpen

6. De student kan zelf aspecten van wereldbeelden ontrafelen, uitwerken, in relatie brengen tot klassieke, ontische, ontologische en metafysische denkbeelden en teksten, en er zich kritisch toe verhouden
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de metafysica identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.</body>

<body>Het vak Inleiding methoden en technieken biedt een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste manieren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek die in de criminologie worden gebruikt. Tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en de hoorcolleges wordt aandacht besteed aan onderwerpen en begrippen die van belang zijn om goed sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te kunnen herkennen en zelf uit te kunnen voeren. Gedacht kan worden aan het formuleren van de probleemstelling, het bepalen van het onderzoeksontwerp (ook wel design genoemd), het kiezen van de methoden van data verzamelen, het operationaliseren van concepten, het kiezen van de technieken om de data te analyseren, de interpretatie van de bevindingen en het doen van uitspraken ten behoeve van de beantwoording van de probleemstelling. Zowel kwantitatief als kwalitatief onderzoek komen bij het vak aan de orde. Tijdens de practica gaan de studenten zelf oefenen met het uitvoeren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Tijdens de kwantitatieve practica wordt met verschillende kwantitatieve analysetechnieken in SPSS geoefend. Ook zijn er kwalitatieve practicumbijeenkomsten waarin de studenten (in kleine groepen) zullen gaan oefenen met interviewvaardigheden.</body>

• de basisbegrippen van methoden en technieken van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek omschrijven en uitleggen;
• design en kwaliteit van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek herkennen, indelen en uitleggen;
• de kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoekscyclus beschrijven en uitleggen;
• uitleggen waarom en wanneer kwantitatief onderzoek en kwalitatief onderzoek wordt gebruikt binnen de criminologie;
• uitleggen wanneer je op basis van onderzoek generaliserende uitspraken kunt doen en bijbehorende kernbegrippen omschrijven en uitleggen;
• verschillende methoden van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve dataverzameling herkennen en omschrijven;
• omschrijven en uitleggen wat beschrijvende analyse en verklarende analyse inhoudt;
• de basisbegrippen van statistische analyse omschrijven, uitleggen en toepassen bij het maken van statistieksommen en het interpreteren van SPSS output;
• zelfstandig met SPSS werken: variabelen definiëren en construeren, en enkele beschrijvende analysetechnieken en verklarende analysetechnieken uitvoeren;
• verschillende soorten interviewvragen kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en zelf formuleren (in een gegeven situatie);
• verschillende interviewtechnieken, houdings- en communicatieaspecten kunnen herkennen, beoordelen en toepassen (in een gegeven situatie).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In dit tweede methodevak van de opleiding Criminologie wordt de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I verdiept. Er wordt een verscheidenheid aan methodes en toepassingen daarvan aangeleerd  met betrekking tot het verzamelen en analyseren van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve gegevens. Na afloop van dit vak is de student er klaar voor om zijn eerste eigen onderzoek te gaan uitvoeren.

Er wordt in dit vak een mixed methods-onderzoek uitgevoerd, waarbij met zowel kwantitatieve als kwalitatieve methoden grootstedelijke problematiek (criminaliteit, sociale veiligheid, armoede en inclusiviteit) in (gemarginaliseerde) wijken wordt onderzocht.

In het kwantitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt de focus op het analyseren van cijfermatige data. Na de beschrijvende analyses die in Methoden en Technieken I zijn behandeld, worden nu methoden geleerd om (complexe) samenhang tussen variabelen te analyseren. Daarbij gaan we uitgebreid in op situaties waarbij meer dan twee kenmerken onderling samenhangen (multivariate analyse).

In het kwalitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt gaan we kwalitatieve data verzamelen via diepte-interviews en (participerende) observaties en deze vervolgens op kwalitatieve wijze analyseren in Atlas.ti. Tevens zullen we kritisch en systematisch reflecteren op de manier waarop we kwalitatieve data verzamelen en analyseren (methodologische en ethische reflectie).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten zijn na dit vak in staat een gefundeerde keuze te maken uit dataverzamelings- en analysemethoden, voor exploratief, beschrijvend, verklarend en toetsend onderzoek. Daartoe hebben zij naast de kennis uit Methoden en Technieken I nu ook inzicht in de basiskenmerken en principes van kwalitatieve dataverzamelingsmethoden als interviewen en observeren en van belangrijke bestaande kwantitatieve databronnen. Studenten kunnen bovendien de gegevens die voortkomen uit kwalitatief onderzoek coderen en analyseren en weten welke methodologische en ethische problemen er kleven aan kwalitatief onderzoek.

Wat betreft kwantitatieve analysemethoden kunnen studenten bivariate en multivariate analyses uitvoeren met variabelen van verschillende meetniveaus en de uitkomsten daarvan interpreteren en daarover rapporteren. Ook zijn studenten in staat methoden en resultatenbeschrijvingen in wetenschappelijke literatuur te begrijpen en kritisch na te gaan of de uitspraken die worden gedaan terecht zijn, gegeven de gebruikte onderzoeksmethoden.
Tot slot kunnen zij hun reflecties en kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve bevindingen integreren en presenteren in één wetenschappelijk eindverslag.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98581,2021,Methoden van Forensisch Handelen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. FCP van der Horst', 'MKM Lunnemann, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit practicum gaan de studenten actief aan de slag met de praktische uitwerking van wat in het algemeen wordt gezien als de basis voor het handelen in het forensisch werkveld, namelijk het risicobeginsel, het behoeftebeginsel en het responsiviteitsbeginsel. Studenten leren (1) op basis van gevalideerde instrumenten het recidiverisico in te schatten, (2) hoe in behandeling te interveniëren op criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van een cliënt en (3) hoe om te gaan met niet-gemotiveerde cliënten en hoe motiverende gespreksvoering toe te passen in de forensische praktijk.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:

column2: • kennis van de in het forensisch werkveld veelgebruikte What works?-principes uit het Risk-Needs-Responsivity model (Bonta & Andrews, 2007; Ward & Stewart, 2003) en daarmee van de uitgangspunten voor effectieve diagnostiek en behandeling in een forensisch kader;;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• zicht op de behandeling van criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van cliënten en kennen zij het onderscheid tussen statische en dynamische risicofactoren;
• zich bewust van algemene werkzaamheid van interventies en de noodzaak in behandeling rekening te houden met specifieke eigenschappen van de cliënt in zijn specifieke context;;
• basisvaardigheden van motiverende gespreksvoering (Miller & Rollnick, 2012) onder de knie.

column1: De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):

column2: • Een samenhangende en heldere rapportage te schrijven;
• Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
• Een casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de BAPD te schrijven.

column1: This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various research methods, the emphasis is on students’ own usage of these methods, specifically at the design and data gathering stages of the research process. The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengths the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. Key research methods in the field are covered in the course, including surveys, in-depth interviews, qualitative content analysis and quantitative content analysis. The various methods are taught by different lecturers who bring their own research expertise to the modules. Thus, each of the four methods is discussed over a period of two weeks and concluded with an assignment where students develop an adequate research design and engage in limited data collection. Thematically, the research designs developed for the assignments in this course cover topics such as popular culture and political communication, or social media.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht  in:

column2: • Gangbare onderzoeksmethoden op het gebied van media en communicatie.
• De voornaamste verschillen in de manier waarop specifieke onderzoeksmethoden worden gebruikt en het soort data dat ze genereren.
• Onderzoek op te zetten en  meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën (met betrekking tot specifieke  methoden) te evalueren.
• Hun eigen onderzoeksopzet, meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën ten aanzien van concrete onderzoeksvragen  over media-inhoud of mediagebruik te ontwikkelen.
• Bruikbare data te verzamelen.
• Op hun gebruik van verschillende onderzoeksmethoden te reflecteren.
• Met collega’s onderzoeksstrategieën te bediscussiëren, te ontwikkelen en te beoordelen.

column1: Er worden in de maanden februari tot en met juni verscheidene seminars aangeboden voor de masterstudenten Beleid en Politiek, AOM, GMCS en Publiek Management over verschillende onderwerpen die van belang zijn bij het ontwerpen en uitvoeren van masterafstudeeronderzoek.
Sommige seminars zijn verplicht voor alle studenten; daarnaast zijn keuzeonderdelen beschikbaar (kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve methoden).

De seminars bestaan deels uit het overdragen van kennis over de specifieke methodologische thematiek van dat seminar, en een gedeelte is gericht op het oefenen en ontwikkelen van de bijbehorende vaardigheden.

column1: Na afloop van het vak zijn studenten in staat:

column2: • Verschillende filosofische benaderingen van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te beschrijven en het eigen afstudeeronderzoek te positioneren in de verscheidenheid van bestaande filosofische benaderingen;
• Keuzes te maken met betrekking tot hoe data worden verzameld en geanalyseerd in verschillende filosofische benaderingen van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek;
• Uit te leggen hoe onderzoeksresultaten kunnen worden gecommuniceerd in een onderzoeksrapportage en op welke wijze resultaten kunnen worden vertaald in aanbevelingen voor de praktijk.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101863,2021,Methodology of Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CJ Clarke'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course will introduce students to key concepts and arguments surrounding:

A) Theoretical modelling: explanation, understanding, idealization and abstraction, causal tendencies, modal hypotheses, the distinction between the practice of theoretical model building and applied models.

B) Causal inference: the Causal Markov assumption, exogeneity, heterogeneity, choosing an appropriate set of control variables, background causal knowledge, Bayesian methods, and hypothetico-deductive approaches in economics, especially Friedman’s instrumentalism.
C) Econometrics: the Lucas critique / microfoundations debates, structural models, the assumptions of regression analyses, representative agent models, methodological individualism

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: By the end of this course, students can:

1) Clarify the aims of idealized modelling in economics, and critically assess whether these models meet these aims, drawing on the debate between Cartwright, Alexandrova, Sugden, Reiss, Maki, Hausman and Till Grune Yanoff.
2) Examine the extent to which economics is value-laden, and evaluate whether this is desirable or undesirable

3) Explain and distinguish the main obstacles to causal inference in economics, both for observational studies using regression analysis or instrumental variables techniques, or for social experiments.

4) Relate these general obstacles to causal inferences in economics to particular issues arising in econometrics, including the debate over microfoundations for macroeconomic models, influential critiques of macroeconomics by Leamer and Roemer.

column1: This course deepens the data analysis expertise which students have gained in prior studies and preparatory trainings. The focus is on some of the most commonly used methods of data analysis in the social sciences, in general, and the field of media and communication, in particular. Half of the course will therefore focus on quantitative methods of data-analysis (such as T-tests, Anova, factor, and regression analysis), while the other half will focus on qualitative methods (such as thematic analysis, discourse analysis and visual analysis). Questions regarding validity and reliability of research will be addressed as well. In the weekly seminars, time will be spent on practicing methods, while the weekly lectures will cover the methodological steps more in-depth and from a theoretical perspective. Students will apply some of the methods they practiced with during the course to complete a qualitative- and a quantitative-methods assignment.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• common methods of both quantitative and qualitative data analysis in media and communication;
• strengths and weaknesses of each discussed method of analysis.
• choose these covered method of analysis that best fits their research design;
• apply the covered methods when analyzing media content, processes, uses, and influences;
• report their analyses in oral and written form.

</style>

column1: This course focuses on qualitative research methods employed in the social sciences, particularly when studying phenomena in culture, media, and history. Whilst various qualitative research methods are contextualized and students are familiarized with their specific characteristics and uses in scientific research, the course is primarily a hands-on course. Students learn how to formulate fitting research questions, design research, and operationalize theoretical concepts. They gain practical experience in various methods of data collection and analysis. The primary focus of this course is on interviewing, but ample consideration will be given to ethnographic field research, narrative analysis, qualitative content analysis, and emerging methods within visual sociology.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After completing the course, students have knowledge and understanding of the characteristics and applicability of a range of qualitative research methods. They will be able to apply particular methods such as participant observation and (semi) structured interviews, and will be able to argue for and against the use of qualitative data analysis methods like grounded theory and (critical) discourse analysis. Apart from a cognitive approach to qualitative research methods, students will learn how to design and execute a research project from proposal to report. The practical application of qualitative research methods is the focal point of this course.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103924,2021,Methods of Sustainable Transitions,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. A Hebinck', 'dr. YH Hendlin']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The methods of sustainability transitions are multiple, and mutually supportive. This course will introduce students to how to take multi-level perspectives, learn the fundamentals of transition management, gain facility with the “X-curve model” to determine where in particular transition one is, map out and take into account multi-actor perspectives, understand the process of how social (urban) experiments in social design get institutionalized, and how the “capacities model” of social change can focus on creating resilience. Students will have the opportunity to critically engage with the Chief Resiliency Officer of the City of Rotterdam, for example, and learn about the different problems (e.g., reform versus restructuring) and crucial opportunities governing sustainability transition encounters. During this course, students will be encouraged to form peer-learning groups of 4 students to participate in reflection and peer learning.</body>

column1: The Master thesis including the thesis proposal constitutes the heart of the master programme MScBA - Master in Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research in one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration and relate and link their insights with managerial insights and relevance. The thesis is perceived as a proof of their academic level of thinking, especially a proof of analytical craftsmanship combined with problem-solving and critical reflection. During the thesis trajectory MiM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analysis and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

By choosing a research topic in a profile students express their special interest and affinity towards a future employer. The thesis trajectory is considered as the main opportunity to bring in a focus in the program and express one’s affinity towards managerial challenges in a field in business administration. The topics as offered for a thesis cover the main domains in business administration, e.g. marketing, strategy, finance, supply chain etc. MiM students are always required to consider and discuss elaborately the relevance and implications for management.  The title of the thesis will be mentioned on the grade list. Therefore, it is recommended to choose a title wisely to indicate one’s interests.  The thesis is written under the supervision of a coach and a co-reader.   Before working on the thesis a research proposal (or: thesis proposal) has to be crafted.

column1: This course forms an introduction to the fascinating domain of microbes, i.e. the organisms (or entities', such as viruses and prions) that cannot be observed with the naked eye, but have a profound influence on the existence of life on Earth. You will get acquainted with the vast and varied microbiological world and will learn that life can appear in many shapes and forms, and can sometimes tolerate the harshest conditions. Clearly, the saying 'everything is everywhere, but the environment selects' by Dutch botanist and microbiologist Baas Becking (1895-1963) is one of the crucial take-home messages of this course. Apart from the general concepts of microbiology, the course will also zoom in on the world of pathogens: the microorganism that can cause disease. General concepts of infectious diseases will be discussed, and pandemics (worldwide epidemics) from the past will be taken as examples of the devastating outcome that certain infections can have on a population. In addition to studying microorganisms, a major part of this course will be devoted to the human immune system, i.e. the molecular and cellular 'system' that is aimed at recognizing and eliminating harmful microbiological intruders in our body. The different constituents of the immune system will be studied, and their role in the battle between pathogens and host will be explained. Finally, we will discuss the therapeutic options that exist in case the immune system fails to eliminate a pathogen from the human body. The mechanisms of action of the various groups of antibacterial (antibiotics) and antiviral drugs will be studied, as well as the role of vaccination in reducing disease burden.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Identify and describe the general characteristics of prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and unicellular (eukaryotic) parasites;
• Understand the evolution of life and the role of photosynthetic bacteria in creating the Earth's atmosphere;
• Explain bacterial metabolism and recognize what is an autotroph or an heterotroph
• Describe viral replication mechanisms;
• Recognize human pathogens: prions, viruses, bacteria, fungi and protozoan parasites;
• Understand the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system and immune disorders;
• Recognize (emerging) infectious diseases and the interplay between pathogen and host;
• Identify and characterize sexually transmitted diseases (chlamydia, gonorrhea, syfilis, genital herpes and human papilloma viruses);
• Explain zoonoses and pandemics (Yersinia pestis (black death), influenza (Spanish flu) and AIDS);
• Understand diagnostics of infectious diseases;
• Explain antiviral and -bacterial drugs and vaccination, and the mechanism of antiviral and -bacterial resistance.

column1: Na een algemene inleiding in de micro-economie zal de aandacht uitgaan naar de keuzetheorie. Uitgangspunt is dat economische handelingen doelgericht zijn: de beperkte middelen die een subject voorhanden heeft worden zodanig gebruikt dat een bepaalde doelstelling bereikt wordt. Dit algemene uitgangspunt wordt op de handelingen van de consument en producent toegepast. Vervolgens komt het functioneren van markten aan de orde. Ook wordt een begin gemaakt met het analyseren van strategische interactie met behulp van de speltheorie.

column1: This course will provide the basic tools and training in microeconomics. It begins with the study of consumer behaviour and how their choices form the basis of demand in an economy. Firm behaviour is studied next to understand the input-output decisions of firms and to see where supply comes from. The third part brings together both sides of the economy and different market structures are discussed. Finally, strategic interaction between economic agents is the topic of the last part. Throughout, applications are provided to help understand why economic theory can be used to study behaviour in the real world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course students will be able to:

column2: • To understand how consumer choice forms the basis for individual demand, and how individual demand translates into market demand.
• To understand the role of information in decision making.
• To understand how firms decide what and how much (output) to produce, and how they decide which resources (inputs) to use for production.
• To understand the concept of a perfectly competitive market.
• To understand what it means for a firm to have extreme market power.
• To understand that in the real world a whole spectrum of market structures exists between the extremes of perfect competition and monopoly.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The first part of the course deals with the theory of the consumer. Topics covered include consumer choice under certainty and uncertainty, and individual and market demand;
• The second part focuses on the theory of the firm, and includes the topics of firm production and firm cost;

• The last part of the course turns to market structures (monopoly, imperfect competition and perfect competition), to the joint analysis of firm and consumer behavior within a market (general equilibrium theory) and to factor markets (especially labor).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Instructors: Prof. R. Sloof (UvA) and Dr M. Watanabe (VU)

Economics is about the creation of value through markets, organizations and other institutions. Asymmetric information and bounded rationality may get in the way of value creation. This course presents a number of insights from contract theory for dealing with these twin problems. It starts with moral hazard and adverse selection in elementary settings, then it turns to multidimensional incentive problems, contracts for teams, relational contracts, incomplete contracts, decision rights and authority, and asset ownership. It also includes a discussion of cheap talk and communication. These topics are approached by applying contract theory to problems in labour economics, organizational economics, and corporate finance.

column1: Instructors: Prof. P.P. Wakker (EUR) and Prof. T.J.S. Offerman (UvA)

This course consists of two parts. One part deals with the behavioral revolution in economics, where differences between homo sapiens and homo economicus require a remodeling of risk behavior, intertemporal behavior, social behavior, individual utility, and, thus, of virtually all economic models. The other part considers the path-breaking insights of behavioral economics into interactive decision making. Special attention will be paid to how behavioral economics changed our thinking about learning, equilibrium, social preferences, strategic communication, and markets. The course gives a broad perspective, showing how behavioral ideas impact virtually every field in economics.

column1: De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

De middeleeuwen beginnen wanneer West-Europa in economisch en cultureel opzicht tot een primitief stadium terugvalt. Eerst rond 800 trad in de kloosterscholen een voorzichtig herstel van de wetenschappen en de wijsbegeerte op. Daar doceerde men een neoplatonisme, dat men onder meer via Augustinus kende. In de twaalfde eeuw ontstaan de eerste universiteiten, waar de wijsbegeerte van Aristoteles de grondslag van het onderwijs vormt. Dit was mogelijk doordat de hele Aristoteles onder meer door vertalingen vanuit het Arabisch wordt herontdekt. Vanaf dat moment oefent zij bijna een half millennium een ‘despotisch’ gezag uit over de geesten. In de cursus zal worden stilgestaan bij de vernieuwingen met name in de metafysica en de kentheorie, die ondanks de conserverende werking van het ‘schoolse’ onderwijs aan de universiteiten plaatsvonden.

De Renaissance wordt - de naam zegt het al - gekenmerkt door de wedergeboorte van de klassieke cultuur. Deze werd mogelijk door het humanisme: het ontstaan van het hermeneutisch probleem. In de filosofie betekende dat de aandacht voor andere vormen van klassiek denken dan Aristoteles. Uit de herleving van het platonisme en het scepticisme komt ook iets nieuws voort: de moderne natuurwetenschap, die in Francis Bacon haar eerste programmatische pleitbezorger vindt. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de zogenaamde ‘pyrrhonistische crisis’ die in de tweede helft van de zestiende eeuw haar eerste woordvoerder vindt in Montaigne.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Overzicht van de verdere ontwikkeling van de filosofie vanaf de oudheid. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen religieuze en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan in het interpreteren van een filosofische tekst uit de middeleeuwen en zich vertrouwd gemaakt met de historische wijsgerige terminologie.</body>

</style>

column1: The region known as the Middle East has been at the centre of global attention for well over a century. Yet it remains an object of widespread misconceptions and seemingly suffers from unique problems that other parts of the world do not experience. But is politics actually that different in the region than in other parts of the world?

This course enables you to gain an understanding of the comparative politics of the Middle East; we will ask questions such as; which structures and practices define politics in the region? Why does authoritarianism hold sway in the region? What is the role of identity and ideology in politics? It will also invite you to look critically at the modes and production of knowledge, combining empirical and critical traditions in Political Science.

The state, a key object of inquiry in Political Science, represents a major theme in the course. Beginning with its historical formation at the end of World War I, we will continue to examine the ideological and coercive apparatuses that underpin postcolonial states as well as the forces that challenge their legitimacy. At the heart of the region’s politics is an ongoing struggle between citizens demanding more democratic institutions and the so-called counter-revolution of regimes defending the status quo. Yet contentious politics manifests itself not only as uprisings against state repression but also in myriad other forms of resistance and the politics of the everyday.

Although grounded in Comparative Politics, this course adopts an interdisciplinary perspective, incorporating Area Studies, Postcolonial Theory, International Relations, Political Economy, and History.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • identify and comprehend major themes in Middle East Politics
• demonstrate insight in historical dynamics and current developments
• locate and explain sources of tension and conflict in the region

column1: Nederland en de meeste andere landen in Europa en Noord-Amerika zijn door doorgaande processen van internationale migratie in toenemende mate etnisch en cultureel diverse samenlevingen geworden. In de literatuur wordt zelfs gesproken van “superdiversiteit” waarmee niet alleen bedoeld wordt dat een steeds groter wordend deel van de bevolking van de westerse landen een migratieachtergrond heeft, maar ook dat daarbij steeds meer verschillende landen betrokken zijn. De minor Migratie en Diversiteit biedt verdiepend inzicht in al zulke vraagstukken van migratie en diversiteit en het op deze gebieden gevoerde overheidsbeleid, zowel in de Nederlandse samenleving als internationaal. De minor maakt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief een analyse van de aard en omvang van internationale migratie, dominante verklaringen voor migratie, en de betekenis van migratie en diversiteit voor de ontvangende samenlevingen in het algemeen. Daarnaast is er in deze minor veel aandacht voor beleidsvraagstukken op al deze gebieden en voor het te zake gevoerde beleid (migratiebeleid, integratiebeleid, stedelijk beleid, enz.). De minor vertrekt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief, maar stelt studenten vanuit andere opleidingen ook in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.
Centrale thema’s in de minor zijn:

column2: • Historische en geografische schets van de voornaamste migratiepatronen wereldwijd, in West-Europa en in Nederland.
• Verklaringen van internationale migratie vanuit diverse sociaalwetenschappelijke disciplines.
• Het ‘management’ van gewenste en ongewenste migratiestromen: visabeleid, grenscontroles, detentie, uitzetting, ‘zelfstandige terugkeer’.
• Theoretische modellen van integratie en integratiebeleid (multiculturalisme, differentialisme, assimilationisme, universalisme en interculturalisme).
• Vraagstukken van vooroordelen en discriminatie, inclusief het gevoerde beleid om dit tegen te gaan.
• De betekenis van migratie voor de samenleving; hoe hebben deze migrantengroepen de Nederlandse samenleving veranderd?
• De gevolgen van diversiteit of “superdiversiteit” voor steden en het beleid dat steden daarop voeren.
• Beleid t.a.v. migranten en diversiteit op verschillende bestuursniveaus: lokaal, nationaal, Europees, internationaal.

column1: De minor vertrekt vanuit sociologisch en bestuurskundig perspectief, maar stelt studenten vanuit andere opleidingen ook in staat om een verbinding te maken tussen de eigen bachelor en de thema’s migratie en diversiteit.

Deze minor valt uiteen in twee verschillende delen. In het eerste deel zijn er in week 1 t/m 6 tweemaal per week hoor- en responsiecolleges van de docenten en soms van gastdocenten. Per college worden studenten gevraagd zelfstandig relevante literatuur te bestuderen. Elke tweede week is er een responsiecollege waarin de student de bestudeerde literatuur kan bespreken met de betreffende docent. Daarnaast bieden de responsiecolleges de mogelijkheid om vooruit te kijken naar de wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of beleidsanalyse die studenten moeten doen in het tweede deel van het programma.
Dit eerste deel van de minor wordt in week 7 afgesloten met een “mid term” tentamen over verplichte literatuur en hoorcolleges.

In het tweede deel van de minor (week 8 t/m 10) schrijven studenten in paren of drietallen (afhankelijk van het aantal studenten) een wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleine beleidsanalyse over één van de eerder in de minor besproken migratie- en/of diversiteits vraagstukken of het ter zake gevoerde beleid. Studenten kunnen het onderwerp van hun afsluitende werkstuk zelf kiezen. Indien gewenst, kunnen ze ook voor een ander onderwerp kiezen als ze daarmee een verbinding kunnen leggen tussen de eigen bachelor en vraagstukken van migratie en diversiteit. Begeleiding vindt plaats door wekelijks bijeenkomsten in kleine groepjes (afhankelijk van studentenaantal 10-15 studenten) o.l.v. één van de drie docenten.
Individueel schriftelijk tentamen (open vragen) over verplichte literatuur en hoorcolleges (“mid term exam”) (60% van het eindcijfer).
In groepjes van twee of drie studenten: wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleinschalige empirische of beleidsanalyse over een migratie- of diversiteitsvraagstuk (40% van het eindcijfer).
Er wordt een inzagemoment met de docenten georganiseerd voor het tentamen.

Gedurende week 8/10 wordt gewerkt met peer-reviews en algemene feedback van de docent bij het schrijven van het paper. Voor de beoordeling van het paper wordt gebruik gemaakt van een beoordelingsformulier. Dit formulier wordt van te voren gepubliceerd op Canvas.

column1: <body>Na afronding van de minor heeft/kan de student:

column2: • kennis van migratiepatronen van nu en uit het verleden, en begrip van de oorzaken en gevolgen van internationale migratie;
• kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische verklaringen van internationale migratieprocessen;
• kennis van het gevoerde migratiebeleid (d.w.z. het gevoerde beleid om “gewenste” migranten te verwelkomen en “ongewenste” migranten te ontmoedigen), zowel landelijk als in Europa;
• kennis van en inzicht in diverse theoretische opvattingen van “integratie” en integratiebeleid (multiculturalisme, differentialisme, assimilationisme, universalisme en interculturalisme);
• inzicht in governance vraagstukken omtrent integratie en migratie waaronder verschillen in beleid tussen landen en tussen diverse beleidsniveaus (Europees, nationaal, lokaal);
• inzicht in vraagstukken van vooroordelen en discriminatie;
• samen met andere studenten een wetenschappelijke literatuurstudie of kleine beleidsanalyse kunnen verrichten op één van de thema’s die in deze minor aan de orde komen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101035,2021,Migratie, diversiteit en criminaliteit",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['M Moussane, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Internationale migratie gaat van oudsher samen met regulering, uitsluiting en restricties. Het zijn processen die zich vooral, maar niet uitsluitend in urbane gebieden manifesteren. Ook wordt migratie al heel lang met criminaliteit in verband gebracht. Door diverse vormen van migratie en de positie en integratie van migranten in m.n. Nederland en Europa centraal te stellen, willen wij in dit vak criminologische en juridische kennis toepassen op een actueel maatschappelijk onderwerp. Thema’s die hierbij aan de orde komen zijn het criminologische taboe op etniciteit; (ir)reguliere migratie en het toezicht op en de beheersing van migratiebewegingen; migratie gerelateerde criminaliteit als mensensmokkel en mensenhandel; de constructie van het ‘integratieprobleem’; racisme, radicalisering en extremisme; beschrijvingen en verklaringen van ‘allochtone’ criminaliteit; de constructie van het ‘illegalenprobleem’, bestaansstrategieën van onrechtmatig verblijvende vreemdelingen, vreemdelingenbewaring, uitzetting en terugkeer. Je verwerft tijdens het vak niet alleen inhoudelijke kennis op deze terreinen, maar maakt ook kennis met de bedoelde en onbedoelde effecten van het Nederlandse en Europese beleid op deze terreinen waardoor je na afloop kunt reflecteren op deze actuele migratie gerelateerde vraagstukken.

column2: </body>

• op basis van de kennis en inzichten die je in dit vak hebt verworven grootstedelijke alledaagse problemen van de multiculturele samenleving op een afgewogen wijze beoordelen en becommentariëren.
• de gelaagdheid en complexiteit van migratieprocessen duiden in relatie tot mogelijke onbedoelde effecten van restrictiever beleid op deze migratieprocessen.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Globalization, understood as the massive increase in flows of goods, services, ideas and people across borders and the widening and deepening of global interconnectedness and interdependence between places, is without a doubt among the most profound societal transformations of the last centuries. By definition, globalization is a transnational, boundary-crossing process that depends on the mobility of not only capital, but also labor. Technological and technical advances have created communication and transportation networks that allow for unprecedented levels of human mobility for transnational elites. Yet, paradoxically, the situation of refugees and ‘undesirable’ migrants is characterized by immobility despite these advances. We will therefore investigate how (im-)mobility is produced, experienced and governed in a globalized world.

In this course, we explore the intricate and complex relationship between globalization and migration in further detail. We draw on insights from the sociological literature on globalization to grasp how global migration brings about changes in various spheres of social life. First, we review sociological theories on the meaning of ‘globalization’ as a process of societal transformation. Next, we investigate the effects globalization has had on the scale, composition and dynamics of migration patterns and, vice versa, how migration has facilitated global change. In the remaining sessions, we further dissect and examine the relationship between globalization and migration by zooming in on its economic, cultural, political and social dimensions.

Throughout, we learn to consider how globalization at times operates as a force of universalization and homogenization and, at other times, as a force of polarization and heterogenization. Globalization can lead to the formation of integrated labour markets, cosmopolitan cultures and transnational social ties, but it can also give rise to global inequality, localism and right-wing populism. Both the ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ of globalization are considered in this course, ranging from hyper-mobile transnational elites to immobilized undocumented workers. Rather than solely conceiving of globalization in trans- and supranational terms, we will also explicitly investigate how globalization manifests itself at the local level.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Learning goals
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• Discuss theories and empirical research on globalization and migration
• Analyse the impact of globalization on global migration patterns and vice versa
• Summarize and present theories and the results of scientific studies on the economic, cultural, political and social aspects of globalization
• Apply theoretical insights from the globalization literature to a case study on or ongoing debate around migration
• Research and write a paper about a subdimension of globalization and its impact on migration

column1: The bachelor’s thesis is an important assessment in the bachelor’s program because it tests the student’s ability to report about their own small-scale historical research. The bachelor’s thesis follows on the bachelor thesis class of a specific focus area. The bachelor thesis is considered as an independent course within the bachelor’s program. Students have to write their own thesis individually, although they can consult their supervisor by appointment. The different focus areas of

column2: • Social History
• Cultural History
• Economic History
• History of International Relations

column1: The bachelor’s thesis is an elaboration of the final paper of the bachelor thesis class. This implies that the students are asked to:

column2: • Specify their research question ;
• Expand their secondary and primary sources (e.g. longer period, more samples, broader geographical reach and/or a comparative approach).

column1: The student has to process the remarks of the teacher of the bachelor thesis class in the bachelor’s thesis. Students can find more information on the assessment criteria of bachelor’s thesis on MyEUR. Deadlines
For students following the Bachelor Thesis Class in term 2; the thesis should be written in term 3.
Theses that are submitted after the deadline will not be marked and will not get a re-sit opportunity.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The student is able to set up a small-scale research project under supervision. The students are able to formulate an elaborate research question which is the starting-point for their bachelor thesis. They can find and critically interpret different types of primary sources and engage with relevant secondary literature to answer this research question and they also are able to apply theoretical and methodological concepts in their research. Finally, the students are able to write an academic report about their small-scale research.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course, we explore the complexities of identities – and why do they matter to begin with – from the multilayered context of globalization since the twentieth century, dubbed the ‘Age of Mobility.’ The contact, exchange and dissemination of cultures as a result of the migration of ideas, goods and people have resulted in diverse and geographically distributed human identities, particularly in the so-called ‘global cities.’ These phenomena have affected virtually all social groups, home and away from home, albeit in different ways. They also have resulted in the integration, co-existence and contestation of diversities. Among those to be discussed include ethnicity, race, class, gender, and religion, as well as the concepts of national belonging, authenticity, materiality, collectivity and other less-conventional identities. Through topics such as language, sports, food, and music, this course aims to sensitize students to the ways in which various actors continuously negotiate the impact of globalization processes on their identities. In addition, students are invited to develop and apply creative and critical skills to their research, including the incorporation of non-written sources and more inclusive historiography.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Upon completing the course, students will learn:

column2: • to critically analyze the complexities and issues involved in identity studies and why they matter
• to identify and contextualize the actors and processes related to mobility that construct, transform or oppress identities
• to produce academic presentations and papers of relevant topics in an analytical, creative and inclusive manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: 'Modernity’, the French poet and angry young man Baudelaire once wrote, ‘is the transient, the fleeting, the contingent (….)’, a formulation that has become as famous for its heuristic power as it has become infamous for its interpretative flexibility. In this course we will discuss this elegant, yet slippery statement on the “essence” of modernity by looking into at least two of its many levels of interpretation, i.e. Modernity’s social structures and its structures of experience.

Modernity, conceived as a historical period, is often sharply distinguished from so-called traditional societies by way of the manifold structural changes that occurred in the nineteenth and eighteenth century (and some would even point to the seventeenth century).

We will discuss this radical break or gradual transformation by means of several key witnesses that have been living through (and sometimes even actively shaped) the developments that have come to define modernity. We will pay particular attention to the Enlightenment and the industrialisation process. By reading texts from Enlightenment thinkers such as Immanuel Kant and Georg W. F. Hegel and critical thinkers such as Karl Marx, Hannah Arendt and Michel Foucault you will gain an understanding of the social situation in which they wrote and the historical moment they tried to grasp in words.

While reading and discussing texts from disciplines such as History, Philosophy and the Philosophy of History, we will focus on four interrelated questions that all circle around the notion of ‘Timely Reflections.’ What is the historical context of some of the most canonical thinkers on modernity? What can these thinkers teach us about their historical context? Why did all of these thinkers reflect on History (with a capital ‘H’) and the relation between the past, present and future? And why are their texts still relevant today?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course students are able to

column2: • Describe and explain in which ways Modernity is rooted in the Enlightenment;
• Describe and explain the emergence of typically modern institutions, such as the state, civil society, the family, and the market;
• Describe and explain the industrial revolution and the industrialization of society;
• Describe and explain the ways in which industrialization is related to wider developments such as the emergence of capitalism and urbanization;
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions produce docile bodies by means of disciplinary techniques.
• Describe and explain the ways in which modern institutions are mobilized and have dissolved with the emergence of totalitarian movements and regimes.
• Describe and explain in which ways Enlightenment Reason has been incorporated and criticized in the dominant tradition of modern (continental) philosophy;
• Describe and explain the ways in which canonical thinkers – i.e. Kant, Hegel, Marx, Foucault and Arendt – have reflected on their own times and the concept of History.
• have an understanding of the continuities and discontinuities in the rise of the natural sciences in the 16th to 18th Century;
• have an understanding of the rise of the social sciences and humanities in the 19th Century;
• have knowledge about the ways in which scientists and others (i.e. non-scientists) engage in engage in discussions on ‘objective knowledge’;
• have a understanding of the consequences of the democratization of science
• have a clear understanding of the relations between science, policy and practice.
• can explain how science and technology are as much the products of the societies in which they are embedded as that the give shape to those societies

column1: This module is part of Blok 9, together with GW309AVV and GW309I.
This module is exclusively for students Gezondheidswetenschappen, BMG.

Many decisions that you will make as a health care manager or policy maker have an ethical component. Think for instance about decisions concerning national vaccination policies, organizational policies that encourage healthy behavior from staff and government and organizational policies emphasizing the autonomy of patients. Different values are at stake in policies such as these which can conflict with each other. This makes it crucially important for you, as a future healthcare manager or policy maker, to be able to recognize the values at stake and to weigh such values in your decision-making. In the course choices and dilemmas we will provide you with the necessary knowledge and skills to do so.

In this course we use insights from the different disciplines of ESHPM, building on the knowledge you gained in previous courses. In addition we use insights from ethical theory to deepen your knowledge about ethical choices and dilemmas. We also provide you with different tools, such as moral deliberation, for ethical reflection.

In the first part of the course we introduce different ethical values (autonomy, nonmaleficence, beneficence and justice) and different ethical theories. In the working groups we practice with several methods of ethical reflection. In the second part of the course we go into more detail on specific ethical dilemmas stakeholders experience in practice. In the working groups we reflect on ethical questions you identify in your internship organizations. In the third and final part of the course you write an individual essay on an ethical question or dilemma of your choosing.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completion of this module, you can:

column2: • Analyze the origin of choices and dilemma’s in healthcare using ethical theory.
• Analyze cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare from different points of view (including different stakeholders, disciplines and ethical theories).
• Use reflective tools such as moral deliberation when analyzing cases concerning choices and dilemmas in healthcare.

column1: This course will introduce you to the fundamental principles of 'life', with a focus on molecular and cellular biology. Cell biology studies the structure, function, and behaviour of cells, whereas molecular biology describes the molecular basis of biological activity between various biomolecules (like DNA, RNA and proteins). The course begins with an overview of the main features of bacterial, plant and mammalian cells and goes on to introduce the key molecular players in the cells, i.e. proteins. Techniques that enable characterisation, isolation, and manipulation of cells and biomolecules are central in molecular and cellular biology, and these techniques therefore also play a principal role in this course. Specifically, we will take a close look at microscopy, cell culture, DNA cloning and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technology. We will then move on to study the regulation of gene expression and the eukaryotic cell cycle. We will see how cells are organised in tissues and how intra- and intercellular signalling pathways are involved in controlling cell division, differentiation, and maintenance of the stem cell state. The final part of the course will focus on how DNA can be damaged and repaired, and which molecular events are involved in the generation of cancer.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After taking this course the student will be able to:
• Understand the principles of biological systematics, taxonomy and the classification of ‘life’;
• Identify and describe the structure of bacterial, animal and plant cells (similarities and differences);
• Recognize the vital compartments and organelles of eukaryotic cells and describe their particular function;
• Explain intracellular sorting and transport of molecules (in animal cells) and how this is related to the cytoskeleton and cell movement;
• Recognize excitable animal cells, understanding membrane and action potentials and the cellular interactions within neural pathways;
• Describe the cell cycle: DNA replication, cell growth and division (mitosis and meiosis);
• Explain molecular genetics and epigenetics: the organisation of genomes (emphasis on the human genome); genes and chromosomes; dominant and recessive alleles; inheritance;
• Characterize signal transduction pathways: from an extracellular ligand to transcription activation;
• Understand the regulation of gene expression: the function of promoters, enhancers, transcription factors and small RNAs;
• Describe the various steps involved molecular carcinogenesis;
• Explain the concepts of DNA modification and cloning, including transgenesis;
• Understand the principles of DNA and (whole-) genome sequencing.

column1: In this practical course, you will become acquainted with microscopy as well as a variety of microbiological and molecular biological techniques. The preparation, planning and execution of the experiments, and the use of specific laboratory materials and equipment, will provide a solid introduction to many aspects of lab work. As a part of the microbiological experiments, you will focus on basic techniques such as the production of culture medium, plating, staining and quantification of bacteria. The molecular biological techniques that you will perform include the isolation of plasmid DNA and determination of the purity of the DNA by spectrophotometry. The length of the isolated plasmid DNA will be determined by both restriction enzyme digestion analysis and PCR. This course provides both practical training, theoretical understanding of the selected methods and the organisational skills required in the biological lab.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: At the end of the course the students will:
• Be able to accurately work with a variable micropipette
• Work according to the general safety rules and the current safe microbial techniques (SMT; in Dutch 'veilige microbiologische technieken' or VMT) rules
• Be able to prepare culture media
• Estimate the quantity of micro-organisms (colony-forming unit)
• Be able to make a DNA UV spectrum and interpret it
• Be able to isolate plasmid DNA from a bacterial culture
• Be able to execute electrophoresis using agarose
• Be able to determine the size of an unknown DNA fragment by means of the electrophoresis data
• Be able to execute a simple PCR experiment and interpret the results
• Be able to operate the light microscope quickly and correctly
• Be able to make various microscopic preparations
• Be able to keep the labjournal in an organised fashion and write lab reports
• Be able to do the calculations involved in these experiments

column1: <body>This course provides an in-depth coverage of the fascinating field of molecular genetics. We will question how many genes it takes to make a human, how these genes are being regulated at the molecular level, and how genome variation contributes to our individuality. Also, we will discuss the clinical manifestation of the patterns of single-gene inheritance and the complex inheritance of common multifactorial disorders. Using this knowledge, we will see how genetics is being used in a clinical setting for risk assessment, genetic screening and counselling. Furthermore, we will study how (defective) genes can be modified both in humans, animals, and plants through gene editing technologies, with the aim of providing gene therapy, or developing transgenic animals and plants. At the end of this course, you will understand that having an exact count of the necessary number of genes will not be nearly as important as understanding the functions of each gene and how they interact to build the living organism.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course you will be able to:

column2: • Understanding the functional differences between genes, pesudogenes and non-coding RNA's
• Ecplain how genes are organized on chromosomes and how they are expressed, i.e. transcribed and translated

• Describe the molecular techniques, such as comparative genomic hybridization (CHG), fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH), quantitative PCR (qPCR), gene expression profiling (array technology), DNA/RNA sequencing using next generation sequencing technology (NGS), which enabl chromosome and genome analysis that are commonly being used for gene mapping and identification, clinical and prenatal diagnosis and cancer cytogenetics
• Understand the relationship between the genome and proteome, and how proteogenomics can provide valuable additional information on the composition of the genome

• Understand the typical Mendelia pattern of inheritance, or the pattern of transmission of single-gene disorders. You will be able to describe the molecular and genetic mechanisms by which mutations in genes result in recessice, dominant, X-linked and mitochondrial inheritance patterns
• Understand the genetics of common diseases with compex, non-Mendelian, inheritancem and how this relates to disease-predisposing alleles
• Explain the difference between genetic and epigenetic inheritance and the difference between and the molecular mechanisms of X-inactivation and the histone code
• Understand how determination of the recurrence risk is an important aspect of genetic counseling
• Explain the difference and underlying mechanisms of genome, chromosome and gene mutations, and be able to interpret the mutation nomenclature
• Understand how genetic polymorphisms - or single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) determine genetic diversity
• Understand the Hardy-Weinberg law in population genetics and how it's used in genetic counseling
• Understand the principles of linkage and genome-wide association studies (GWAS)
• Explain how susceptibility traits can have high or low risk allele frequency and what the impact of risk allele frequency is on clinical phenotype
• Understand what gene knock-out is and how molecual techniques, such as the Cre-lox and Crispr/Cas systems, enable gene modification in transgenic animals and plants
• Explain how and what type of viruses are being used for enabling gene therapy, and which diseases can be targeted
• Recognize and understand the ethical issues that are connected to prenatal and diagnostic screening, genetically modified organisms (GMO's), and gene therapy

column1: Monetary economics is a very broad topic area that deals with the effects of money, monetary institutions, and monetary policy on macroeconomic variables such as economy output, inflation, interest rates, and exchange rates. In this course we discuss some key theoretical principles behind the monetary policy and the practical issues of its implementation by various central banks.

column2: • What is money and what does it do?
• Interest rate policy of central banks and the effects on financial markets.
• The various transmission channels of monetary policy.
• Monetary policy rules and reaction functions.
• Understanding inflation. Why has price stability become the cornerstone of the modern monetary policy?
• Lessons for the monetary policy from the global financial crisis of 2007-2009
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand key theoretical principles behind the modern monetary policy.
• Learn practical issues of monetary policy implementation by various central banks.
• Learn the transmission channels of monetary policy monetary policy to macroeconomic outcomes such as output, inflation, and unemployment.
• Read academic and policy papers related to monetary economics
• Work with the economic data and use econometric techniques in order to empirically test the key relationships between monetary and macroeconomic variables.

column1: <body>The goal of this minor is to provide students with the key concepts that are critical to understanding how the financial system, the banking system, the money supply process and monetary policy work. Some of the questions addressed in this course are:

column2: • What is money and how is it created in the financial system?
• How do capital and money markets work?
• How are interest rates on different bonds determined?
• What is the role of commercial banks and central banks?
• Why and how are banks regulated?
• Why can financial crises have such devastating consequences for the real economy?
• How do central banks implement conventional and unconventional monetary policy?
• How does monetary policy transmit to the real economy?

column1: All these questions will be discussed in the context of current developments in financial markets and economic policies. A special emphasis will be put on recent academic and policy debates. For example,

column2: • What are the pros and cons of very low interest rates for the banking system and the economy as a whole?
• How do unconventional measures such as quantitative easing work?
• Can cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin or Libra take over the role of traditional fiat money?
• How does the Covid-19 shock affect different economies around the world?
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Following this course, students are able to…

column2: • Compare the financial system of different countries
• Illustrate the functions of money, financial intermediaries and the money supply process
• Analyze moral hazard and adverse selection problems in financial markets using a formal model, and how these frictions can be overcome by financial intermediaries
• Discuss the inherent instability of banking in a formal model and how it is addressed by financial regulation
• Investigate the build-up, the evolution and amplification mechanisms of financial crises throughout history using different models of financial crises
• Discuss the function of central banks and how monetary policy affects the real economy through different channels in a domestic and international context

• Calculate relevant concepts around interest rates including present value, yield to maturity, expected return, the risk- and term-structure of interest rates, as well as the difference between nominal and real interest rates

column1: In this course, students will analyze the tension between fine arts and money, and the problems of commercializing artistic processes. The course will be divided into two parts: in seminars 2 to 4 we will discuss different exchange models for art goods illustrated by historical and contemporary case studies, and in seminars 5 to 8 the focus will be on the specifics of contemporary art markets (prices, values, indices, rules and conventions, and actors).

column2: • gain an understanding of - and be able to explain the different exchange models for art goods;
• picture the main characteristics and actors of the market for fine arts;
• understand, explain and compare the exchange dynamics within contemporary art markets;
• become familiar with tools (datasets and methods) available to assess prices in contemporary art markets.

column1: Note: - The maximum number of participants is 20.

column2: • Due to the subject matter of the course, students are required to have a good knowledge of art history.

column1: The aim of this course is twofold: to gain insight into the economic dimensions of the art world; and to alert students with a variety of interests (like business or society) to the intricate and often problematic interaction between the art world on one hand and the world of money and finance on the other.

Having completed the minor, students will have gained a cultural-economic perspective. They should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective and of the structures and dynamics of art markets.
