column1: The 2007/8 global financial crisis and 2011 Euro crisis demonstrate the importance of well functioning financial markets and organizations. In addition, banks play a crucial role in the allocation of capital and credit in the economy. This course teaches you to recognize the common mechanisms behind current and past crises.

First, you will conceptually understand how money and credit are connected and created. These processes help shape a financial system that can INHERENTLY lead to crisis periods. We will then use these concepts to better understand how the 21-st century financial system actually works.

The second half of this course will zoom in on banks, and in particular on the relationship between a bank, a borrower and a depositor. We will discuss the influence of asymmetric information on the functioning of a bank. We will deal with the theory concerning bank runs, deposit insurance, credit rationing and pooling of interest and maturity. We describe how banks came to existence and how they manage the risks involved in supplying credit. The last lecture is destined for discussion of the current financial crisis.
Main topics of this course are:

column2: • Financial systems and the link between money and credit:
• Money, credit, and central banks:
• The creation and sudden evaporation of elasticity in the financial system:
• The reason of existence of banks and their characteristics:
• The relationship between a borrower and a bank (adverse selection, moral hazard, limited liability, credit rationing and risk management):
• The relationship between a depositor or a stockholder and a bank (bank run, deposit insurance and bank regulation).
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• At the end of this course, students should understand the mechanisms through which money and credit markets work, and roles and functions of banks.
• Students khow these characteristics have contributed to recent crises, and may contribute to future crises.
• Students will know how to classify financial institutions in terms of a money/credit hierarchy.
• Understand and use models that describe how banks work.

column1: <body>This course can best be described as a practical internship in legal psychology. Students are assigned an investigative assignment by the moot court. To fulfill the assignment, an expert witness report has to be produced. First, a strategy has to be determined and an initial draft of the report has to be written. Students will receive peer review of their concept expert witness report. Once the report is complete, students will be questioned orally about the report. During the course, several lectures will be given, in which topics regarding expert witness reporting are targeted.</body>

column1: What is right and wrong, virtue or vice? What ought we to do? What is the (Highest) Good? The course considers normative ethics and discusses four major moral theories that attempt to formulate basic principles of morality: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism. We will also turn to meta-ethics and moral psychology to discuss more foundational issues: What are the background assumptions of the theories? Where do they show their limits? And what about their applicability to concrete moral problems in different fields of moral agency? We will discuss so called “moral dilemma cases”. In such cases, agents seem to be condemned to moral failure, they have a choice between plague and cholera. In which way and to what extent can each of the four theories help to evaluate and / or (re-)solve such dilemmatic situations?
The course is accompanied by a training of philosophical debating skills.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: As a student of the introductory course into Moral Philosophy you will learn how to argue in a critical philosophical debate about major theories of moral philosophy and their application to so called “moral dilemma cases”.
To reach this aim we will proceed in the following steps:
1. You will understand the four major moral theories: virtue ethics, deontology, utilitarianism and contractualism.
2. You will learn to compare the four theories as well as different theories of “moral dilemmas” by reference to a meta-ethical perspective.
3. You will reflect about the criteria of a sound philosophical debate.
4. You will critically evaluate the scope and limits of the four theories by means of applying them to “moral dilemma cases”.
You are expected to read the mandatory literature thoroughly and to participate actively in fair and objective discussions.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98721,2021,Motivatie, zelfregulatie & prestaties",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Twemlow'],,"Inhoud

Why do some people perform better than others on work or study related tasks? Why does one person manage to faithfully adhere to an exercise regimen or a healthy diet while others succumb to the temptation of fast-food? Why is it sometimes difficult to put forth the effort to take on a task? Why do you sometimes postpone tasks even though you know you will regret this later? Why are some good intentions doomed to fail from the start? What is the purpose of planning ahead and setting goals? How can people be properly motivated to reach their potential and reach their objectives? These are just some of the central questions within the domain of motivation, self-regulation, and performance that will be addressed in this course. In addition to a short overview of the major theoretical frameworks, you will read empirical research on these topics. Emphasis is put on critical reading of the literature. The theoretical frameworks or topics that will be addressed are emotion regulation, control theory, social cognitive theory, achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, procrastination, and the possible limitation of willpower.
At the end of the course:

column2: • Students are able to differentiate between and compare the different theoretical frameworks on motivation and self-regulation (e.g., achievement goal theory, self-determination theory, regulatory focus, ego-depletion).
• Students are able to apply these theories on situations in daily life.
• Students can give examples of self-regulatory mechanisms and are able to describe these mechanisms.
• Students can describe the relationship between motivation, self-regulation, and behavioral outcomes (e.g., performance, learning outcomes, health).
• Students can give examples and explain situations of self-regulatory failure (e.g., procrastination).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Tot voor kort was de pedagogische en onderwijskundige wetenschap vooral gericht op wetenschappelijke studies op het gebied van westerse populaties en culturen. Dit heeft voor een westers vooroordeel in kennis en theorie gezorgd. Door mondialisering en migratie ontwikkelingen kan deze kennis over pedagogische en onderwijskundige zaken niet automatisch meer toegepast worden op andere culturen of etnische minderheidsgroepen in Nederland. In de afgelopen jaren is echter veel onderzoek verricht en zijn theorieën ontwikkeld die fenomenen op het gebied van opvoeding en onderwijs in multicultureel perspectief kunnen beschrijven en verklaren. Dit onderzoek en deze theorieën staan centraal in dit blok. Enerzijds worden de basistheorieën behandeld zoals acculturatie theorieën. Anderzijds komen theorieën aan bod die op ontwikkeling en opvoeding betrekking hebben en theorieën die over het onderwijs gaan.

Daarnaast leren de studenten niet alleen over methodologische en theoretische zaken met betrekking tot de wetenschappelijke studie van multiculturele gemeenschappen, maar zij worden ook aangemoedigd om een kritische en beschouwende blik en een ethische en onbevooroordeelde houding te ontwikkelen in de studie naar de ontwikkeling en onderwijs van kinderen vanuit een multicultureel perspectief.

column1: The ‘global South’ can be considered the birthplace of many of the intersecting ideas on resistance, solidarity and social justice that today resonate across the world—think of Black Lives Matter and calls to decolonise educational systems, for instance. This course is an invitation to explore such entangled histories with the global South at its centre, and seeks to highlight voices and perspectives that have traditionally been un(der)-represented in traditional curricula.

Through a combination of texts and audio-visual materials, we will think through global history from a non-Western perspective. The starting point is the idea of ‘multiple modernities’: differing experiences departing from the notion of ‘modernity’ as standing in for Western civilisation. We will study the global South as a politically, economically, and culturally imagined space by adopting the Global History approach within the study of history.

By critically engaging with the histories rooted in the production of knowledge that has generated binary oppositions in geographies (‘North/South’, ‘East/West’, ‘developed/developing’, ‘First/Third World’) and relations (insider/outsider, inclusion/exclusion, us/them, coloniser/colonised, rich/poor), we will look at the power dynamics inherent in such binaries and connections that transcend them.

An online project will have you build an archive as both a method as well as a tool to reframe and reconstruct ‘forgotten’ or ‘silenced’ histories. Topics covered in the course include revolution, (colonial) violence, and the struggles of decolonisation, including attempts to forge transcontinental solidarities. Finally, we will look at our own historical moment and think through the present-day reverberations of colonialism and racism, as well as the promise of potential history.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and describe the scholarly debate on the roots of ‘Western Civilization’.
• Formulate a personal position within the scholarly debate.
• Trace the evolution of ‘the Other’ in ‘Western’ and ‘Eastern’ societies from Ancient times to the present.
• Problematize ‘Europe’ as a cultural construct.
• Compare concepts of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Trace the current-day iconography of ‘Holy War’ in Christian and Muslim societies.
• Discuss the link between Ancient Greek, Muslim and ‘Western’ thinking on the relationship between the spiritual and the temporal.
• Explain the decolonization process in the African continent.
• Critically analyze (political) debates on the role of China in the African continent.
• Explain the basic history of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Discuss the current day cultural, economic and political effects of Transatlantic Slavery.
• Explain Edward Said’s critique of orientalism.
• Explain Samuel Huntington’s theory of the Clash of Civilizations.
• Position a historically and theoretically underpinned view within the discursive debate on ‘East’ and ‘West’.

column1: Companies currently have many sources of data available. In this course, we focus on multivariate relations in the data. This course deals with various multivariate statistical techniques to analyze such data sets. Examples are:

• Factor analysis

column1: The course also contains the introduction to robust statistics and its interplay with the multivariate statistical methods.

column1: This course is about museums. The institution will be analysed from an interdisciplinary perspective to discuss the complexity of the context in which institutions operate. The museum is a firm that acts as key player in the heritage market, as intermediary, as judgement devise, as producer of sustainable assets, as generator of jobs, but also as communicator of what society values, an important touristic destination and overall source of joyful cultural consumption. There are museums of every imaginable topic with varied organisational and financing structures, large and small, with a different approach to being digital and exhibition practices. They all affront challenges in the current heritage market.

Every year, a selection of museums will present one current challenges, giving students the opportunity to apply a strong interdisciplinary theoretic framework to the hands-on case.  Students will work in groups to analyse and explain the problem in order to draw recommendations that will culminate in a proposed plan of action for the institution.

column1: This course offers a law-and-humanities approach to core topics of law and justice, with a special emphasis on their interrelation. We will discuss these topics by means of a reading of some literary classics and relevant legal and philosophical texts. What happens to you if you are suddenly arrested without knowing why? Can you make a contract to give up a body part if you don’t deliver your part of the deal? How do you defend someone who is already condemned by the community? By reading works of literature we get a sense of the different ways in which law may relate to justice. By confronting literature with legal texts the special character of law becomes clear. In doing so we will not only read books, but also pay attention to the films based on these stories in order to address questions of form and function of narrative in the literary and the legal text and on the screen. For example, in what way can and/or does the narrative influence our interpretation of a text or a film? This is an especially pertinent question for law since the act of interpretation is the core of doing law.”

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Have gained insight into the relevance of knowledge of narrative and interpretation for law and legal practice.
• Have gained a basic to develop their ability to reflect on their knowledge in writing.

column1: In dit vak besteden wij aandacht zowel aan nationale geschillen als aan grensoverschrijdende geschillen. In toenemende mate zien wij geschillen met een internationale dimensie, waarin vragen van internationaal privaatrecht spelen: welk (materieel) recht is toepasselijk op de zaak, welke rechter is internationaal bevoegd en hoe het zit met de grensoverschrijdende erkenning en tenuitvoerlegging van een eventuele uitspraak? Als de procedure zich afspeelt voor de Nederlandse rechter, betekent dat niet dat zich geen ‘grensoverschrijdende’ vragen kunnen voordoen, zoals vragen rondom internationale betekening, bewijs dat uit het buitenland moet worden verkregen en toepasselijkheid van ‘buitenlands’ materieel recht. Ook voor de ontwikkeling van het procesrecht wordt steeds meer gekeken naar de wijze waarop het procesrecht elders is ingericht en in de EU zijn de eerste stappen gezet naar harmonisering van procedures.

Na een introductie in de leerstukken, begrippen en rechtsregels van het internationaal privaatrecht, zullen wij ter aanvulling op en verdieping van het bachelorvak burgerlijk procesrecht een aantal actuele procesrechtelijke thema’s behandelen vanuit nationaal en internationaal perspectief. De actuele discussie in Nederland over de verhouding tussen rechter en partijen komt aan de orde en biedt een aanknopingspunt om ons te verdiepen in het fenomeen forumshopping, dat vooral in internationale zaken een rol speelt. Incassozaken grijpen wij bijvoorbeeld aan om de ontwikkelingen rond digitalisering en vereenvoudiging van procedures te bestuderen alsook de vragen die spelen in internationale zaken om grensoverschrijdende incasso te vergemakkelijken (harmonisering van procedures). Een ander voorbeeld van een thema dat in dit vak aan de orde zal komen is (de modernisering van) het bewijsrecht. De bewijsgaring biedt een mooi aanknopingspunt om over de grenzen te kijken. Deze en andere actuele aspecten van het nationaal en internationaal procederen zullen na de tussentoets in de seminars van dit vak centraal staan. In dit vak wordt tevens een brug geslagen naar de praktijk door de aandacht voor ethische dilemma’s in de beroepspraktijk.</body>

column1: Het Studentenparlement is een landelijke debatwedstrijd die elke 2 jaar wordt georganiseerd door de staatsrechtsdocenten van alle rechtenfaculteiten in Nederland, onder auspiciën van de Staatsrechtkring. De bedoeling is dat elke faculteit een fractie van 3 tot 8 studenten afvaardigt die een standpunt formuleert over een - door een werkgroep van docenten opgesteld - fictief wetsvoorstel. Net als bij de wetgevingsprocedure voor de Tweede Kamer is er eerst een schriftelijke fase (in de periode oktober - februari) en vervolgens vindt in mei een mondeling debat tussen alle fracties plaats in de vergaderzaal van de Tweede Kamer.

Een onafhankelijke jury - doorgaans bestaande uit een hoogleraar staatsrecht, een of meerdere politici en een parlementair journalist - beoordeelt vervolgens de prestaties van de verschillende fracties. Winnaar is die fractie die zowel in zijn bijdrage aan het Verslag, als in het mondelinge debat de beste prestatie heeft geleverd, dat wil zeggen met het oog op het politieke karakter van het evenement, zo goed mogelijk heeft gedebatteerd.</body>

column1: dr. Meike Morren (VU) and prof. dr. Bas Donkers (EUR)

Natural Language Processing (NLP) comprises statistical and machine learning tools for automatically analysing text data to derive useful insights from it. Vast amounts of information are stored in this form, and hence NLP has become one of the essential technologies of the big data age. In this course, core concepts and techniques from the area will be studied, with a focus on methods that are popular in business applications. These include n-gram and word vector coding, sentiment analysis, word embeddings and topic modelling.

This course offers students a theoretically informed understanding of NLP. It aims at broadening the knowledge of the methods involved in NLP, as well as a hands-on experience with the steps that need to be taken in an NLP project. We focus on three aspects:
a) to create deep(er) understanding of the main methods in NLP (n-gram, lexicon approach, word embeddings and other advanced machine learning methods);
b) to obtain an experience to scrape and clean the data yourself;
c) to apply this knowledge and experience in a group assignment which gives you the possibility to show your creativity.

By the end of this course, you will be able to analyse and evaluate NLP approaches. Moreover, you will apply this knowledge and skills in a real-life setting, enabling you to translate and apply theoretical knowledge into practice.
1. Information theory, regular expressions and scraping (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing).
2. Word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams)

column1: By the end of the course students will be able to:

Knowledge and Understanding:  Demonstrate knowledge of Natural Language Processing, from data cleaning to advanced machine learning approaches, including: Information theory, regular expressions, scraping and data cleaning (tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, parsing); word vectors and dimension reduction based on bag of words (n-grams, PCA); sentiment analysis (lexicon-based vs model-based); topic models (LDA); word embeddings (Word2Vec, GloVe, BERT)
Application of Knowledge: Apply this theoretical knowledge and experience in group assignments. Analyze and evaluate NLP approaches.
Making judgement: Evaluate the effectiveness of marketing expenditure, evaluate the appropriateness of a model
Communication: Written and oral presentation of results within the research project.

• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni).
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen.
• In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
• Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

column1: Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op luisteren en communicatie in een alledaagse context. Tijdens de lessen word je geacht actief deel te nemen aan de conversatie- en mondelinge opdrachten.

Om het beste uit de lessen te halen, wordt er van je verwacht dat je elke week je huiswerk maakt en de woordenschat te oefenen. Houd er rekening mee dat het geen passieve lessen zijn, waarbij je alleen luistert, teksten leest en zinnen vertaalt.

• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.

• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij online cursussen is het maximum 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
• Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

column1: Deze cursus bestaat uit 10 wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2 uur. Er is geen afsluitende toets maar tijdens de cursus geeft de docent feedback op je spreekvaardigheid.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands Spreekvaardigheid?

Na het behalen van niveau B2 kun je je goed redden in het Nederlands maar om de taal goed en vlot te gebruiken moet je blijven werken aan je spreekvaardigheid en het uitbreiden van je woordenschat. In deze cursus wordt niet of nauwelijks geschreven maar ga je discussiëren over actuele onderwerpen en bespreek je interessante teksten. Elke les leer je een paar  nieuwe uitdrukkingen en of spreekwoorden. Ook oefen je met presenteren in het Nederlands en lees je thuis een Nederlands boek dat in de les met elkaar besproken wordt.

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>Aan het einde van de 18e eeuw ontwikkelt zich in Duitsland stormachtig het Duits idealisme op basis van de problematiek die Kants kritische filosofie deed ontstaan en die hij  in zijn derde kritiek probeerde te entameren. De basis van dit denken is Kant, met name diens teleologie, dat als model dient voor een geschiedfilosofie, die de geschiedenis leest als een proces van menselijke bevrijding en emancipatie. Hegel meende dat na de Franse Revolutie en Kants kriticisme dit proces zowel in politiek als intellectueel opzicht voltooid is met de opbouw van de moderne (rechts)staat en het ontstaan van een christendom dat tot zijn redelijke kern zou zijn herleid. Rond 1830 begint Hegels roem te verbleken.</body>

</style>

column1: Overzicht van de ontwikkeling van de negentiende-eeuwse wijsbegeerte te beginnen bij Kant. Na deze cursus is de student in staat het verband te leggen tussen politieke en wetenschappelijke ontwikkelingen aan de ene  en de wijsgerige ontwikkelingen aan de andere kant. Verder heeft de student een praktische vaardigheid opgedaan jet het interpreteren van filosofische teksten uit de 19e eeuw.

column1: In de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw II’ wordt inhoudelijk voortgebouwd op de ideeënhistorische context, de filosofische stromingen, ontwikkelingen en debatten die in de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw I’ zijn geïntroduceerd. Hierbij worden de volgende thema’s in chronologische volgorde en in hun onderlinge samenhang behandeld.

Ten eerste de opkomst van het vooruitgangsdenken in Frankrijk, Engeland, Nederland en de Verenigde Staten, waarbij achtereenvolgens aandacht wordt besteed aan de ideeënontwikkeling van de grondlegger van het positivisme, Auguste Comte, de bloei van het utilitarisme in Engeland, zoals in gang gezet door Jeremy Bentham en verder uitgebouwd door John Stuart Mill, de unieke ‘ervaringswijsbegeerte’ van Cornelis Willem Opzoomer en het Amerikaanse pragmatisme van Charles Sanders Peirce en William James.

De invloedrijke theorie van natuurlijke selectie van de ‘philosophical naturalist’ Charles Darwin staat in de tweede week centraal, zij het ruim ingebed in het bredere debat over evolutie en de positie van de mens in de natuur, waarbij ook dieper wordt ingegaan op de ideeënontwikkeling van de eerste darwinisten en sociaal-darwinisten.

In de periode waarin Darwin zijn theorie ontwikkelde (1830 – 1860) worden ook de eerste contouren zichtbaar van een nieuwe filosofische discipline: wetenschapsfilosofie. Hoe zich dat proces voltrok middels baanbrekende publicaties van John Herschel, William Whewell, John Stuart Mill en Ernst Mach vormt het eerste thema. Het tweede thema in deze derde week is geheel gewijd aan het in politiek-maatschappelijk opzicht uiterst invloedrijke historisch materialisme van Karl Marx.

In de laatste week worden in aansluiting op de behandeling van het neo-kantianisme in de cursus ‘Negentiende Eeuw I’ onder de noemer ‘van pessimisme tot Umwertung’ de filosofieën van twee zeer uitgesproken, karakteristieke denkers uit de negentiende eeuw behandeld, te weten Arthur Schopenhauer en Friedrich Nietzsche.

column1: 1. Beschrijven van de belangrijkste filosofische stromingen in het Negentiende-Eeuwse Engeland, Frankrijk, Duitsland en Nederland.

2. Uitleggen van de filosofische begrippen die de inhoudelijke filosofische discussie in de negentiende eeuw kenschetsen. Voorbeelden van begrippen zijn onder andere neo - Kantianisme, idealisme, vooruitgangsoptimisme, positivisme, uniformitarianisme, transcendentalisme etc.
3. Leren samenvatten middels het maken van collegedictaat.
4. Het schriftelijk logisch onderbouwen van een eigen filosofische stellingname ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.
5. Het schriftelijk evalueren van een eerder ingenomen filosofische stellingname (zie 4) ter voorbereiding op een werkcollege.

column1: Being able to negotiate successfully is essential in establishing and maintaining fruitful business relationships and transactions. In this course, we utilize a psychological perspective to develop professional negotiation skills. We will focus on cognitions, emotions and motivations that impact the negotiation process and outcomes, and explore different negotiation strategies and their outcomes in terms of potential value, efficiency and relationship quality. We will also address some basic knowledge about individual decision making. This course is very hands-on and will give you ample opportunity to practice your negotiation skills by learning how expand the pie and create value.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Upon completion of the course, students are able to:

column2: • Understand and prepare effectively for different negotiation situations by applying    relevant knowledge;
• Understand how cognitions, emotions, and motivations influence negotiations and utilize this knowledge when choosing a negotiation strategy;
• Create and claim value in negotiations by knowing how to expand the size of the pie;
• Evaluate academic research on the relevant psychological mechanisms in negotiations.

column1: Negotiation is one of the most important skills that a manager should have in his or her professional life. In our curriculum, however, this important skill has been underemphasized. This course aims to help you be a better negotiator. I will provide you with negotiation tools to effectively persuade others. The specific topics of this course include seeing and expanding the pie, dealing with someone who has a very different perspective on the world, disagreeing respectfully and productively, etc.

column2: • This course aims at targeting students who do not have a background in behavioral economics. If you have such a background, I advise you not to sign up for this course.
• This course may have some overlap with Dr. Hesam Fasaei’s Strategic Decision Making course. I advise you not to sign up for my course if you have taken that course.

column1: Social Networks shape many aspects of how people and organizations interact, take decisions, and ultimately perform. With the advent of Social Media (e.g., Facebook and Twitter) and with the increasing digitization of all forms of communication and business processes, Network Analytics has become a valued asset to better understand how different agents interact and how to best take advantage of the network structure to increase overall system performance. This course will cover the fundamentals of network science, the methods, theories, and the procedures for data collection and analysis in very large social networks. Covered topics include clustering, information diffusion, organizational design, viral marketing, social media and others.

This course provides the basics of network data analytics, including fundamental network- and node-level metrics, as well as more advanced analysis methods, with attention to the application areas where these can and have been used. Students will engage in in-class projects in which they collect and analyze network data using the tools and methods covered in class. Students will apply these methods to specific networks, such as social media networks (e.g., Twitter), co-worker networks, organization networks, and product networks.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: This course will teach you the fundamental skills for decision making based on social network data. Specifically, you will learn:

column2: • How to use R for analysis of network data;
• How to represent network data;
• Techniques and tools for social network analysis and visualization;
• How do networks form;
• Which types of network structures foster and hinder performance in specific contexts;
• How to use social network data to inform decision making.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: <body>In our current network society governments increasingly face so called ‘wicked problems’. Concrete examples of ‘wicked problems’ are the uncontrolled influx of refugees and its societal implications, attempts at inner city regeneration, conflicts over the construction or operation of public infrastructures (e.g., roads, airports and windmill parks), health and social problems like obesity, drug use, safety and criminality, and lack of coordination in elderly and youth care. These problems are characterized by:

column2: • The involvement of a large number and broad diversity of actors
• The strong (resource) interdependencies between governments and other involved actors
• The lack of consensus about the nature of the problem and the desired solutions
• The complexity of the issues at stake and the lack of adequate and accepted information and expertise on these issues

column1: These problems are addressed in networks of interdependent actors. The autonomous position of the actors and their (diverging) individual strategies makes decision- and interaction processes in networks complex. In the course Network Governance, we explore these complex governance processes in depth, drawing on theoretical concepts of network governance and practicing network analysis through the analysis of a concrete case.

Students will be introduced to theoretical concepts of governance networks and network governance to enable them to understand and analyze the interdependence between government and society. To that end, concepts such as networks, dependencies, perceptions and different aspects of the complexity of network governance processes will be dealt with.

Students will also learn to interpret, understand and analyze networks and the governance processes that take place within these networks. Finally, students will analyze, assess and design management strategies in order to influence networks and network processes. The interaction between theory and practice is the main focus of the course. In tutorials students will practice with the concepts discussed during lectures and use the concepts to make assignments and conduct an in-depth case analysis (the core of the paper to be written).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After following this course students must be able to:

column2: • Describe in their own words what the core concepts of the Network Governance approach are and why they are relevant to the analysis of problem solving and public service delivery.

• Explain the differences between the Network Governance approach and traditional approaches to problem solving and public service delivery, more specifically the traditional bureaucratic Public Administration model and New Public Management.
• Assess real-world examples of complex decision-making processes using core concepts of the Network Governance approach.
• Design network management strategies that promote collective action in situations characterized by interdependencies between actors.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102954,2021,Networked Datascapes in Participatory Platforms,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CS Ritter', 'dr. HJCJ Hitters', 'dr. V Chaudhri']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: As the platformization of media industries continues around the globe, cultural production and digital consumer markets are increasingly disrupted by participatory platforms. Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and other participatory platforms transformed business models and the diffusion of content within the media industries. For instance, the ways in which cultural events are promoted and brands are advertised changed substantially. This practical research workshop examines how different stakeholders in the media industries seek to capitalize on the participatory dynamics of platforms. A defining feature of platforms is their application programming interface (API). The Facebook Cambridge Analytica data scandal irreversibly brought the role of APIs to public awareness. APIs facilitate the flows of data between platform owners, users, and third parties. API-stored data can be repurposed for media research and provide insights into the ‘popularity’ of content creators, their audience engagement, and their connected communities.

In this workshop, students are given the opportunity to explore social network data from pivotal platforms, such as Twitter, GitHub, and YouTube. They will learn how content creators pursue coordinated online strategies, such as campaigns, product placement, and audience enlargement. The data sets primarily contain information on content creators, which are considered as network nodes, and digital traces of their platform practices, such as ‘mention’, ‘reply’, ‘comment’, ‘retweet’ and ‘collaborate’, which are considered as network edges. All students will conduct an individual, small-scale case study in which they analyze network visualizations. In doing so, they will formulate a research question, search for appropriate literature, and collect and analyze relevant data to answer their research question.

• Students will be able to distinguish natively digital data and digitized data;
• Students will learn to use advanced search operators for Twitter and YouTube content;
• Students will be able to create and interpret network graphs in Gephi and Visone
• Students will learn the state-of the art theory on the subject of the workshop.
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical study on a workshop theme;
• Report on their findings in oral and written form;
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research;
• Consult media firms on strategies for online campaigns.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98922,2021,Neuroeconomics: how the brain decides,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Genevsky', 'dr. MAS Boksem', 'dr. RM van Diepen', 'LD van Brussel, MSc', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts', 'SPH Speer, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Economics, psychology, and neuroscience are converging today into the unified discipline of Neuroeconomics with the aim of providing a single, general theory of human choice behaviour. Neuroeconomics can provide social scientists and future managers with a deeper understanding of how they make their own decisions, and how others decide. How is a “good” or “fair” decision evaluated by the brain? What does our brain perceive as valuable? How do we learn the value of features of our environment? Is it possible to predict the purchasing intentions of a consumer? Are we hard-wired to be risk-averse or risk-seeking?

Neuroscience combined with psychology, economics and management theory provides powerful models and advanced brain-research methods to explain how and why people make certain choices. Risky decision-making in financial markets, the role of emotions versus rationality, competition and cooperation in teams, consumer persuasion, are some of the central issues in this course in neuroeconomics. You will be provided with the most recent evidence from brain-imaging studies, and you will be introduced to the explanatory models behind them.

The course will consist of three modules. In Module 1: “Introduction to Neuroeconomics”, we discuss the history of neuroeconomics and provide a crash-course on the anatomy of the brain, as well as an introduction to neuroscience methods. In addition, we will investigate the balance between rationality and emotions, and provide a brief introduction into decision-theory form both a psychologist and an economist perspective. In Module 2: “How the Brain Decides”, students will be presented with the main theories and neuroscientific findings accounting for how the brain makes (optimal) economic choices. We will focus on the neural mechanisms of the computation of value and preference, and how the brain deals with risk and losses. In addition, this module focuses on social aspects of decision-making: how group-membership and social interactions shape individuals’ decision-making. Finally, the practical applications of brain research in the fields of economics, marketing, business, and other aspects of society will be discussed in Module 3: “The Brain in Society”.

Each lecture will be given by a researcher with specific expertise on the topic. Lecturers either have a background in cognitive neuroscience or in economics and management research, and they are all collaborating in the Erasmus Centre for Neuroeconomics (see our website for further information: www.erim.nl/neuroeconomics ).

Students are required to show active participation in the course by attending the lectures and actively participating in the discussion forum (see below). The basic concepts of the course will be examined by means of a written research proposal.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completion of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Name and identify the brain areas involved in choice behaviour.
• Select the appropriate (neuro)scientific method for investigating different aspects of choice behaviour.
• Explain which cognitive processes (decision parameters, heuristics) produce certain biases in choice behaviour.
• Name and identify the brain areas that constitute the brain’s reward and punishment systems.
• Explain how these systems work together to produce choice behaviour and apply this knowledge to explain various choice phenomena.
• Name and identify the brain mechanisms that are involved in social choice behaviour.
• Explain individual differences in choice behaviour by referring to the underlying neurobiological mechanisms.
• Apply your neuroscientific knowledge to come up with methods to improve choice behaviour in real life.

column1: In short, you will be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain everyday choice behaviour in terms of the cognitive processes involved.
• Understand and explain these cognitive processes in terms of the involved neurobiological mechanisms.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99596,2021,Neuromarketing,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MAS Boksem', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces the interdisciplinary field of neuromarketing. This new and exciting area in marketing aims to understand the neurobiological mechanisms underlying customer responses to marketing actions, and to better predict customer behavior using brain markers.

Neuromarketing is proposed to reveal information about customer preferences and reactions to marketing actions that other techniques cannot provide (Ariely and Berns, 2010). This is based on the assumption that customers are not always able or willing to express their true preferences in questionnaires. Furthermore, measures of brain activation could assist in the early stages of the product development process thus reducing the likelihood of failures.

In recent years, the application of neuroimaging and psychophysical techniques in marketing has surged both in academia and in marketing practice. Modern brain imaging techniques of electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are commonly applied, for example, to track the emotional response to brands and TV commercials, to assess which scenes of a commercial attract attention and are memorable, to evaluate the beauty of a package or how customers trade-off price and quality. Psychophysical techniques such as eye-tracking, galvanic skin response and heart rate measurement add additional insights into the customers’ heart and mind.

Currently, most marketers are not trained in these techniques and thus have difficulty in properly evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of these methods. Clients of neuromarketing companies may get easily impressed by colourful pictures of activations in the brain which may not be truly insightful or predictive. In this course we provide the student with an up to date insight into the current body of knowledge in consumer neuroscience and neuromarketing. Accordingly, this course will provide many hands-on opportunities to develop neuromarketing skills. In assignments, the main neuroimaging techniques of fMRI and EEG will be introduced. You will collect data and learn the basics of analyzing this data.
Ariely & Berns (2010), Neuromarketing: The hope and hype of neuroimaging in business, Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 11(4), 284-292

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand the basic anatomy and working of the brain
<li>
Understand the main neural processes underlying consumer decision making and consumer reactions’ to marketing actions (i.e., branding, advertising, design and packaging, pricing, assortment)
<li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind the neuroimaging methods of fMRI and EEG
<li>
Ability to collect, analyze and report basic fMRI and EEG data
<li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind psychophysical methods (in particular, eye-tracking, face reading, heart rate and galvanic skin response)
<li>
Draw inferences from neuromarketing data in order to answer descriptive and predictive questions relevant to marketing managers
<li>
Explain and justify managerial recommendations from neuromarketing studies to non-technical audiences through written reports and presentations
<li>
Understand the main opportunities and challenges of modern neuroscientific and psychophysical methods for marketing purposes

column1: Een beschadiging aan de hersenen resulteert veelal in cognitieve, emotionele, en gedragsproblemen. De psycholoog die werkzaam is in de gezondheidszorg zal deze patiënten vaak tegenkomen. Denk maar aan slachtoffers van een verkeersongeval, mensen met een herseninfarct of patiënten met de ziekte van Alzheimer. Tijdens het blok zal je vertrouwd worden gemaakt met technieken om mensen met een hersenbeschadiging te diagnosticeren en met technieken die het mogelijk maken om functies van de hersenen te bestuderen. Daarnaast wordt er in het blok aandacht besteed aan biologische modellen van psychopathologie. Tegenwoordig is dit een belangrijke stroming binnen de psychiatrie, denk maar aan de diverse psychofarmacologische behandelingsmogelijkheden van psychiatrische patiënten.

In dit blok wordt aandacht besteed aan de toepassing van theoretische kennis en richtlijnen in klinische situaties. Studenten werken daarbij in teams aan blokopdrachten, die geevalueerd zullen worden met een voldoende/onvoldoende.

column1: Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

column1: Most students from RSM will be confronted with new business development at some stage in their careers. This course aims to serve as a pilot test for you, assessing your strength and weakness in entrepreneurial practices. To do so, this course will collaborate with multiple companies and provide tangible business projects for you, with the aim to address real business challenges related to new business development. As a result, you will face the full complexity of new business development. To assist you navigate the project, a reference contact from the company will actively work with you during the six weeks of the course.
No textbook is required for this course. The course are highly practical.

column2: • The core component of this course is the project you work on. You are expected to draw upon your own experience and expertise (e.g. by bringing in relevant tools, methods, theories from prior courses, etc.) to address the new business development opportunities/challenges.
• The guest lectures will consist of exemplary venturing experiences and reflections at startups or established firms.
• All the workload comes from the project you and your team members will be working on, and assignments in the course function as milestones to facilitate your progress on your project.
• The grading has four components: final business plan (40%), presentation of the final business plan (25%), individual reflection (25%), and contribution added in the classroom (10%).
• The information in this document is under regular reservation. When you sign up, please check Canvas for the most-up-to-date information.
• You will be the unfortunate attendees of the course in which the professor does not know what he’ll be doing. But the course has been receiving super good evaluations in the past years.

• Gaining a critical attitude towards the understanding of new business development practices in context with significant time and resource constraints.
• Putting entrepreneurial theories into practice by interacting with the business community in a complex, real business case.

<body>Towards behavioural economics 2.0? Several proposals have been made to move (behavioural) economics beyond the stage in which economics has been enriched by psychological findings and insights. In this course, several directions are identified and discussed: Brains, Evolution, Morality, Complexity, Culture and Welfare & Policy.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the end of this course, students will have developed an informed and nuanced overview of several directions in which behavioral economics can further evolve. Testimony for this will have to be provided by writing an research paper in which students show that they have a clear idea about the about both the prospects (merits and demerits) of behavioural economics moving forward into one of these directions.

column1: The aim of this course is to explore new economic futures by critically engaging with innovative entrepreneurs and following academic debates of socio- economic transitions. Even though more and more companies acknowledge their responsibility to contribute to global issues like climate change, poverty and resource scarcity, they often struggle to develop alternative business models and value propositions that help to guide and accelerate transitions to a sustainable economy and society. Hence, in this minor, we focus on understanding transitions and the role traditional and transformative businesses can play in these long term change processes of economies, sectors and societies.
As part of the Minor we will address several points:

* We will provide you with an overview of research on sustainability transition theory, social entrepreneurship, new business models and new value propositions from an interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary perspective, combining insights from economics, management and transition studies.
* We will support you to become familiar with alternative business models, and ways how businesses change and innovate in response to societal transitions.
* We will support you to better understand how societal change occurs and to map sustainability transition dynamics.

* Business challenges and opportunities of diffusing such innovative business models will be discussed from an academic and practitioners’ perspective including financing, management and governance lenses.
* Attention will be paid to the value proposition of impact thinking and impact measurement.

* You will work in groups on an empirical study in which you will apply your new academic knowledge and insights on a practical case (i.e. carrying out a consultancy project to develop a business advice in collaboration with a social enterprise). At the end of the course, each group of students will pitch their ideas and suggestions to entrepreneurs and representatives from business during a “Dragon’s Den” event.
Examples are new business models based on circular/sharing economy, social entrepreneurship or impact investment. </body>

column1: 1. Describe the complex nature of social, economic and environmental challenges of our society and explore the role of societal transitions;

2. Characterize theoretical concepts, frameworks and methods on sustainability transitions, new economic thinking and business models; 3. Explain the (potential) role of business as a transformative force using theories of new economic models, value propositions and societal transitions;
4. Assess debates around new economic thinking using transition and impact thinking;
5. Identify the ways a social entrepreneur can contribute to a new economy based on theories about new business models, value propositions and societal transitions

You will engage in critical debates and be able to reflect critically upon offered theories. Multidisciplinary perspectives, applied research and problem oriented learning approaches have your interest. As this minor is delivered in English, you need to have a sufficient command of the English language in speech and writing to actively participate in class. We strongly encourage students from diverse disciplines to apply.
Several research centers contribute to this minor as well as the economic students association:

column1: This seminar is focused on understanding the impact of new communication technologies on the Marketing and Advertising Industry. This industry is continuously using creativity to face the challenges of an ever-changing media landscape that urges brands and companies to reinvent the way they communicate with their customers. During this course, we will explore how brands are taking advantage of the quick innovations in the communications and creative industries to persuade customers in new and innovative ways. We will also critically reflect on the value and implications of these new forms of branded communication. We will reflect on how these are perceived by customers but also how much value they have for brands. Finally, we will also learn how to apply the theoretical knowledge acquired during the course to design efficient new media marketing campaigns.
The NMMA strategies discussed in this course include: personalized advertising, branded entertainment, gamification and playful marketing, and influencer marketing.

column1: New media and social media have become central to everyday life, and how these can be used effectively within international business has become an important topic for business and communication research. From mobile apps and gaming to social media including Instagram, Facebook and Twitter, new media have changed the way international business gets done. While these changes have transformed logistics, resource management and hiring practices, this course will specifically focus on how new media have affected (and been affected by) marketing practices and the growing importance of social media as a channel of strategic communication. That is, the course will focus on two areas. First, it will evaluate marketing practices that employ new media, most specifically the practices on social media through Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, YouTube, and more. Second, the course will look at a new wave of marketing strategies that involve influencers, participatory publics/audiences, gamification, and fandoms.

In the first few weeks of the course, students will be oriented to a practice theory focused approach to understanding the use of new media in context, exploring readings and examples ranging from traditional media to videogames to the rise of independent content creators. This is then further focused on the three focus areas within the course. During the latter part of the research workshop, students will engage in qualitative research focused on new media and international business, examining the practices and technologies involved in the marketing of specific media/mediated products – streaming content, videogames, apps, theme parks, and music, among others. They will, through the use of qualitative and/or mixed methods, empirically examine the ways in which companies and content creators promote themselves through social media as part of a marketing strategy, how they interface with each other and users in creating buzz about new products, how gamified advergames are used to enhance attraction (and also, at times, mislead consumers), and other related topics. In order to gain both conceptual and methodological knowledge, students will take several reading comprehension quizzes, engage in in-class exercises, group work, develop their own line of research, execute and present on research work that is subsequently integrated into a final research paper.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • How marketing and business practices shape markets through various technologies and techniques
• Differentiated levels of control (and their implications) attained by international businesses in the use of new and social media (with particular attention to marketing and human resources)
• How new and/or social media choices affect the distribution and control of information and communication
• The use of empirical cases studies in studying new media practices
• Develop and execute a small research project either focusing on new media and marketing or new media and workplace contexts
• Effectively research new media practices through empirical case studies
• Evaluate practices within international businesses, focusing on the potentials and problems that come with the use of new media
• Define problematic potentials for practices and policies within international business in relation to new media
• Report their research findings in a scientifically substantiated manner
• Work with (international) peers and reflect on their own development

column1: Back in the mid-1990s, the rapid popularization of the Internet had raised the hope of technologically-enhanced citizen engagement in political decision-making. How did the vision of an electronic democracy, where new media enable citizens to monitor and participate in the life of their polis, turn out in practice? On the one hand, our own use of new media is oriented towards consumption and entertainment. On the other, political content circulated online is often dubious or problematic, while political debates online often become heated and even toxic. From cyberwarfare and fake news, to citizen digital activism, online political communication appears to be in a state of constant transformation. Each year, the instructor focuses the course around a salient topic in the field of online political communication (e.g. deliberation; populism; etc.) asking how citizens and politicians engage in political talk online and to what effect on the quality of our democracies and or our polities. In addressing the topic, we focus on the ways in which new media both hinder and enable political communication. Since the secondary purpose of this course is to improve your empirical research skills, you develop and conduct a small research project on the topic of the course. You gain methodological knowledge and skill necessary for assessing and doing scientific research. The course thus improves your qualitative research knowledge and skill. Furthermore, the knowledge about online political communication gained in this course improves your own civic performance and prompts you to consider how, as a communication professional, you can help create democratic communication.

column1: This is an exciting and transformative moment for creative industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers.

The main goal of this research workshop is to help students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.

Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the creative industries from a variety of publicly available sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

column1: Entertainment and cultural products shape the identities of audiences and fans all over the world. Music, TV shows, movies, videogames and anime are all different ways of contacting with different cultures and connecting with strangers. In a time where nationalism and divisions are on the rise in some parts of the world, this course explores how people connect, share experiences and produce new content related to their favorite cultural products. How do fan groups and forums organize themselves online? How do cultural products create conflicts or encourage friendships? What is the impact of new media on community building? Do entertainment products help bridge tensions and reduce polarization between different groups?

Using quantitative content analysis, we will learn how to conduct research in the world of entertainment and explore the interactions between cultural products and audiences. Furthermore, students will learn that research about communities and new media is not limited to the field of entertainment, but that similar research methods and concepts can also be applied to other communication fields like brand communities and national identities.

column1: Perceptions of the political are evolving due to widespread transformations in society and new media play an important role in these transformations. Yet, the debate on whether advances in new media technologies are impacting democracy positively or negatively remains complex and open to constant revision. This seminar looks at the role that new media (particularly social media, but also more classic forms like websites and blogs) play within such an evolving political context with a focus on political campaigns. Throughout the course, we build a theoretical background allowing us to assess contemporary dimensions of (internet) politics. For our discussions, we focus on three types of campaigns: electoral, grassroots (or citizen-led), and public information campaigns. Each week, we introduce the relevant debates and classical concepts associated with each type of campaign. We then explore how these debates and concepts are affected by the reliance on new media. In the end, this helps us inquire into how political campaigns are evolving (or not) in relation to new media, and how communication via new media impacts the political world.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Current theoretical perspectives on the intersections between new media and political campaigns.
• The role of new media in a democratic society.
• Common research methods of analyzing the role of new media in political campaigns.
• Analyze new media in a broad political framework.
• Critically reflect on the impact of new media in the political arena.

column1: In this course students are introduced to various advanced marketing research techniques.
In marketing often rich data are available in customer databases or in reviews and blogs on the web. The techniques introduced in this course enable firms to transform these data into knowledge.
At the same time little information is available about consumer preferences for new products. In these cases efficient data collection and analysis are needed to obtain knowledge at low cost.

Students will develop a deeper understanding of the techniques introduced in the course. They will also learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences. Finally they will learn how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.

column2: <title></title>

</style>
• Students will develop a deeper understanding of several marketing research techniques related to online marketing and consumer preference measurement.
• Students will learn how to design and analyze conjoint choice experiments to study consumer preferences.
• Students will practice how to present consumer preference research results and to evaluate and interpret the outcomes of such research.
• Students will practice writing a team research report.

column1: Friedrich Nietzsche speelt een cruciale rol in de ontstaansgeschiedenis van de hedendaagse filosofie en spreekt ook vandaag nog tot de verbeelding. Binnen het omvangrijke oeuvre van Nietzsche is de Vrolijke Wetenschap een laat werk waarin veel van zijn cruciale thema’s –ziekte en gezondheid, naturalisering van de moraal, esthetica, de dood van God, de eeuwige wederkeer en perspectivisme – een bijzonder scherpe formulering vinden en met elkaar in verhouding worden geplaatst. Door de structuur van het boek (vijf ‘boeken’ met aforismen van uiteenlopende aard en lengte) is elke lezing van het boek tegelijkertijd een filosofische oefening. In dit vak wagen we ons aan die oefening door de Vrolijke Wetenschap van kaft tot kaft te lezen en gezamenlijk te reflecteren op de inhoud. Hiervoor worden gevarieerde werkvormen gevonden – van klassieke instructie tot thematische discussie en gezamenlijke close reading van de primaire tekst.

- zijn studenten in staat Nietzscheaanse thema's die betrekking hebben op het zelf en het leven, zelfbevestiging en zelfverloochening te verhelderen in relatie tot kunst, wetenschap, moraliteit en waarheid.
- hebben studenten hun vaardigheden op het gebied van close reading aanzienlijk verbeterd.

</style>

column1: Companies increasingly supplement financial performance measurement and disclosures with non-financial information on aspects of their business activity. Examples include, but are not limited to, forward-looking nonfinancial indicators such as customer satisfaction, employee turnover, and online engagement, as well as metrics related to environmental, social, and governance (ESG). Nonfinancial metrics can provide relevant information to stakeholders that help to broaden the scope of performance measurement, contributing to an integrated perspective on performance that has implications for internal decision making, investors, and other external stakeholders, as well as, more broadly, firms’ roles within society.

This course focuses on the importance of nonfinancial performance information. It takes a multitude of different perspectives to answer the question of what role different nonfinancial performance measures play for different stakeholders. We start by taking an economic perspective and exploring how different nonfinancial performance measures can be either direct antecedents of financial performance or indirectly contribute to it. From this perspective we will discuss linking strategy with performance measurement as well as how aspects such as corporate governance contribute to optimized managerial decision making and value creation. Second, we will move beyond the relevance of nonfinancial performance for the individual firm to include a broader perspective on the relevance of ESG performance for various stakeholders and society at large. Third, we will take the perspective of the digital transformation.  We will explore firms’ changing needs for performance measures beyond profitability, the particular needs of firms with digital business models, and the growing possibilities to employ novel, digital measures of performance. Finally, we take the perspective of reporting to reflect on the needs of various groups of stakeholders and learn about forms of mandated and voluntary nonfinancial reporting around the world.

Overall, students in this course will learn about—and critically reflect on—the role of nonfinancial performance analysis for firms’ internal decision-making, valuation by investors, and society at large, thereby deepening their understanding of value creation and the important role that finance and accounting play in this regard.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• After following this course, the student is able to:
• Understand how nonfinancial performance can be measured and gain an overview of frequently used non-financial performance metrics.
• Understand how nonfinancial performance measures drive internal decision making and value creation.
• Comprehend the role of solid governance structures and executive compensation design in enhancing performance.
• Evaluate the (economic) value creation based on reported ESG / non-financial performance.
• Comprehend arguments for the importance of ESG performance beyond firm-level economic rationale.
• Understand how the digital transformation changes companies’ needs and possibilities to measure performance.
• Learn about the emergence of new, digital measures of nonfinancial performance and their growing importance for firm value in digital markets.
• Understand current legal requirements regarding the reporting of nonfinancial metrics.
• Reflect on the desirability and circumstances determining the useful application of non-financial performance metrics and ESG reporting frameworks.

column1: ​This course addresses a variety of political and social (i.e. non-market) boundaries, which, when considered along with market boundaries, help us understand why some firms thrive and others struggle. The non-market is a sometimes-neglected arena, which can severely limit or enable firms in doing business and influence their strategy. Eventually non-market boundaries can affect firm success, while they are particularly challenging to navigate since non-market actors differ in their motives, objectives and tactics relative to conventional market actors. Overall, the non-market opens up questions calling for strategic answers: How do firms incorporate interests of non-market actors, who are not (primarily) concerned about wealth maximization? How do firms draw the line between and manage their ‘duty’ to their constituents (i.e. non-market strategy) and their obligation to shareholders (i.e. market strategy)? What are the benefits and perils of corporate political and social engagement? Ultimately, is the management of non-market interests a means to an end, or an end in itself? In this elective, we will address these questions and discuss how firms are affected, and how they can themselves affect their non-market context. This will help us understand non-market strategy, why some firms thrive, while similar ones may struggle in the politically and socially colored market.

• Discuss different non-market strategies, as well as the integration of market and non-market strategies.
• Analyze key issues faced by firms in the non-market context.
• Evaluate firms’ non-market issues with strategic tools and methods.
• Devise a strategic plan to address a firm’s issues in the non-market.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Consumers generate a digital footprint by using various technologies in their everyday life, such as mobile applications, internet browsers, and wearables. Marketing analysts benefit from the variety and volume of data that consumers generate online as this provides very detailed information at individual level. Such data can be used to (1) improve measurements of consumer preferences and attitudes, and (2) offer better product recommendations. Given the volume of data, analysts are often using machine learning algorithms and are primarily interested in prediction accuracy. While prediction is very valuable for businesses, understanding the drivers of consumer behavior can provide additional benefits to companies.

This course starts with an introduction to theories of consumer attention, search, and choice that are used as a foundation for building advanced quantitative models and marketing strategies. Then, students learn how to combine theoretical insights with quantitative models in order to develop attribution models and recommender systems. Because digital footprints often contain personal or sensitive consumer level information, topics related to the ethical use of data and models are covered.

There will be 8 lectures (2h long) 4 workshops (3h long). The workshops are a mix between a lecture and a lab tutorial. The lecturer shows examples in class and then students work on their own application - in groups of 5-6. The four workshops will be given in computer rooms / labs. The sessions are not taught in a traditional way – I will not spend 3h to show you step by step exactly what you need to do. Instead, you are required to thoroughly study the materials before coming to the session, and then ask relevant questions during the lab. In other words, individual study before the workshop is necessary in order to fully participate in these sessions. If you do not study beforehand, you won’t be able to ask the right questions in class, which might hold up your progress on the assignments.

</style>

column1: Students who actively participate in all sessions and successfully complete their assignments will be able to:
•    Implement advanced methods to collect digital footprints.
•    Recognize legal and ethical aspects that impact how companies collect and use digital footprints.
•    Explain database structures and write code that manages large datasets (e.g. join two or more tables, filter, aggregate, summaries).
•    Perform statistical analyses of large datasets containing digital footprints.
•    Provide managerial and policy recommendations supported by empirical results and theoretical insights from studying the literature.</body>

column1: In zowel wetenschappelijk (ortho)pedagogisch onderzoek als in de professionele praktijk is het gedegen kunnen observeren en registreren van interacties tussen kinderen en volwassenen van groot belang. Deze observaties vormen de basis voor allerlei wetenschappelijke conclusies en professionele (stappen tot) interventie. Kennis van verschillende observatie- en registratiemethoden en codeersystemen (zoals verschillende schalen en variatie in gedragsduur/intensiteit/frequentie), alsmede de voor- en nadelen van deze methoden en systemen is nodig voor een goed begrip van de interactiepatronen tussen volwassenen en kinderen. In dit practicum worden verschillende observatiemethoden en codeersystemen geschikt voor de kindertijd tot de adolescentie behandeld. Ook komen de ethische aspecten rond het gebruik van observaties aan bod en wordt de validiteit en betrouwbaarheid van observaties besproken. Het practicum wordt afgesloten met een eindverslag.

column1: <div>Aan het einde van dit practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • op basaal niveau gebruik te maken van codeerinstrumenten / registratiemethoden (eindterm 6);
• knelpunten rond de validiteit en betrouwbaarheid van observaties te beschrijven (eindterm 14);
• de interbeoordelaarsbetrouwbaarheid (Cohen’s kappa) te berekenen en te interpreteren (eindterm 14);
• knelpunten rond de ethiek van observaties te beschrijven (eindtermen 13 en 14);
• kritisch te reflecteren op codeerinstrumenten en eigen observaties (eindtermen 14, 18 en 19);
• observaties objectief te rapporteren (eindterm 15);
• wetenschappelijke literatuur vinden en selecteren bij een specifiek onderwerp (eindterm 13);
• methoden en empirische resultaten van observatieonderzoek te rapporteren met toepassing van een wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl (eindterm 15);
• peerfeedback te geven en ontvangen en op basis hiervan eigen werk kritisch te beschouwen en te verbeteren (eindtermen 18 en 19)
